# United States

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

"United States of America", "America", "US", and "USA" redirect here. For the
landmass comprising [North](/wiki/North_America "North America") and
[South](/wiki/South_America "South America") America, see
[Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas"). For other uses, see [America
(disambiguation)](/wiki/America_\(disambiguation\) "America
\(disambiguation\)"), [US (disambiguation)](/wiki/US_\(disambiguation\) "US
\(disambiguation\)"), [USA (disambiguation)](/wiki/USA_\(disambiguation\) "USA
\(disambiguation\)"), and [United States
(disambiguation)](/wiki/United_States_\(disambiguation\) "United States
\(disambiguation\)").

-100](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=United_States&params=40_N_100_W_)

The **United States of America** (**USA**), commonly known as the **United
States** (**U.S.**) or **America** ([/əˈmɛrɪkə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English")), is a [federal republic](/wiki/Federal_republic "Federal
republic")[14][15] composed of 50 [states](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state"), a
[federal district](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), five major
[self-governing territories](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States
"Territories of the United States"), and [various
possessions](/wiki/United_States_Minor_Outlying_Islands "United States Minor
Outlying Islands").[fn 6] At 3.8 million square miles (9.8 million km2)[17]
and with over 324 million people, the United States is the world's [third- or
fourth-largest country by total
area](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area "List of countries and
dependencies by area")[fn 7] and the [third-most
populous](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population "List of
countries and dependencies by population"). The capital is [Washington,
D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), and the [largest city by
population](/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population "List of United
States cities by population") is [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York
City"). Forty-eight states and the capital's federal district are
[contiguous](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States") and
located in [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America") between
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). The
[state of Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") is in the northwest corner of North
America, bordered by Canada to the east and across the [Bering
Strait](/wiki/Bering_Strait "Bering Strait") from [Russia](/wiki/Russia
"Russia") to the west. The [state of Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") is an
[archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago") in the mid-[Pacific
Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean"). The U.S.
[territories](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the
United States") are scattered about the Pacific Ocean and the [Caribbean
Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea"), stretching across nine official
[time zones](/wiki/Time_in_the_United_States "Time in the United States"). The
extremely diverse [geography](/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_States "Geography
of the United States"), [climate](/wiki/Climate_of_the_United_States "Climate
of the United States"), and [wildlife](/wiki/Fauna_of_the_United_States "Fauna
of the United States") of the United States make it one of the world's 17
[megadiverse countries](/wiki/Megadiverse_countries "Megadiverse
countries").[22]

[Paleo-Indians](/wiki/Paleo-Indians "Paleo-Indians") [migrated from
Asia](/wiki/Settlement_of_the_Americas "Settlement of the Americas") to the
North American mainland at least 15,000 years ago.[23] [European
colonization](/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas "European
colonization of the Americas") began in the 16th century. The United States
emerged from the [thirteen British colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen
Colonies") established along the [East
Coast](/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United
States"). Numerous disputes between [Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") and the
colonies following the [French and Indian War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven
Years' War") led to the [American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution
"American Revolution"), which began in 1775, and the subsequent [Declaration
of Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United
States Declaration of Independence") in 1776. The war [ended in
1783](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1783\) "Treaty of Paris \(1783\)") with the
United States becoming the first country to gain independence from a [European
power](/wiki/Colonial_empire "Colonial empire").[24] The [current
constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
was adopted in 1788, with the first ten amendments, collectively named the
[Bill of Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of
Rights"), being ratified in 1791 to guarantee many [fundamental civil
liberties](/wiki/Natural_and_legal_rights "Natural and legal rights"). The
United States embarked on a vigorous expansion across North America throughout
the 19th century, [acquiring new
territories](/wiki/United_States_territorial_acquisitions "United States
territorial acquisitions"),[25] [displacing Native American
tribes](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars "American Indian Wars"), and gradually
[admitting new
states](/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_date_of_admission_to_the_Union "List of
U.S. states by date of admission to the Union") until it spanned the continent
by 1848.[25] During the second half of the 19th century, the [Civil
War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") led to the outlawing of
[slavery](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United
States").[26][27] By the end of the century, the United States had extended
into the Pacific Ocean,[28] and its economy, driven in large part by the
[Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution"),
began to soar.[29] The [Spanish–American
War](/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War "Spanish–American War") and [World War
I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") confirmed the country's status as a global
military power. The United States emerged from [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") as a global
[superpower](/wiki/Superpower "Superpower"), the [first country to develop
nuclear weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_the_United_States "Nuclear weapons
and the United States"), the only country to [use them in
warfare](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of
Hiroshima and Nagasaki"), and a [permanent
member](/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council
"Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council") of the [United
Nations Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United
Nations Security Council"). During the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"),
the United States and the Soviet Union competed in the [Space
Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), culminating with the [1969 moon
landing](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11"). The end of the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") and the [collapse of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet
Union") in 1991 left the United States as the world's [sole
superpower](/wiki/Hyperpower "Hyperpower").[30]

The United States is a founding member of the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"), [World Bank](/wiki/World_Bank
"World Bank"), [International Monetary Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund
"International Monetary Fund"), [Organization of American
States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American
States") (OAS), and other international organizations. The United States is a
highly [developed country](/wiki/Developed_country "Developed country"), with
the world's [largest economy by nominal
GDP](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(nominal\) "List of countries by GDP
\(nominal\)") and [second-largest economy by
PPP](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(PPP\) "List of countries by GDP
\(PPP\)"), accounting for approximately a quarter of global GDP.[31] The [U.S.
economy](/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States "Economy of the United States") is
the fastest-growing in the [Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas")[32][33] and
is largely [post-industrial](/wiki/Post-industrial_society "Post-industrial
society"), characterized by the dominance of
[services](/wiki/Service_\(economics\) "Service \(economics\)") and
[knowledge-based](/wiki/Knowledge_economy "Knowledge economy") activities,
although the manufacturing sector remains the second-largest in the world.[34]
Though its population is only 4.3% of the world total,[8] Americans hold
[33.2% of the total wealth in the world](/wiki/National_wealth "National
wealth"), the largest share of global wealth concentrated in a single
country.[35] The United States [ranks among the
highest](/wiki/International_rankings_of_the_United_States "International
rankings of the United States") nations in several measures of socioeconomic
performance, including [average wage](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage
"List of countries by average wage"),[36] [human
development](/wiki/Human_Development_Index "Human Development Index"), [per
capita GDP](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(nominal\)_per_capita "List of
countries by GDP \(nominal\) per capita"), and productivity per person.[37]
The U.S. is the foremost [military](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United
States Armed Forces") power in the world, making up a third of [global
military spending](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures "List of
countries by military expenditures").[38] It is also a global leader in
[science and technology](/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States
"Science and technology in the United States").

## Etymology

See also: [Naming of America](/wiki/Naming_of_America "Naming of America"),
[Names for United States citizens](/wiki/Names_for_United_States_citizens
"Names for United States citizens"), and [American
(word)](/wiki/American_\(word\) "American \(word\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Amerigo_Vespucci_-
_Project_Gutenberg_etext_19997.jpg/140px-Amerigo_Vespucci_-
_Project_Gutenberg_etext_19997.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amerigo_Vespucci_-
_Project_Gutenberg_etext_19997.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Amerigo_Vespucci_-_Project_Gutenberg_etext_19997.jpg "Enlarge")

The _Americas_ are named after Italian explorer [Amerigo
Vespucci](/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci "Amerigo Vespucci").[39]

In 1507, the German cartographer [Martin
Waldseemüller](/wiki/Martin_Waldseem%C3%BCller "Martin Waldseemüller")
produced a world map on which he named the lands of the Western Hemisphere the
_[Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas")_ in honor of the Italian explorer and
cartographer [Amerigo Vespucci](/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci "Amerigo Vespucci")
([Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): _Americus Vespucius_).[40]
The first documentary evidence of the phrase "United States of America" is
from a letter dated January 2, 1776, written by [Stephen
Moylan](/wiki/Stephen_Moylan "Stephen Moylan"), Esq., [George
Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington")'s [aide-de-
camp](/wiki/Aide-de-camp "Aide-de-camp") and Muster-Master General of the
[Continental Army](/wiki/Continental_Army "Continental Army"). Addressed to
[Lt. Col. Joseph Reed](/wiki/Joseph_Reed_\(politician\) "Joseph Reed
\(politician\)"), Moylan expressed his wish to carry the "full and ample
powers of the United States of America" to Spain to assist in the
revolutionary war effort.[41][42][43] The first known publication of the
phrase "United States of America" was in an anonymous essay in _[The Virginia
Gazette](/wiki/The_Virginia_Gazette "The Virginia Gazette")_ newspaper in
Williamsburg, Virginia, on April 6, 1776.[44]

The second draft of the [Articles of
Confederation](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation"),
prepared by [John Dickinson](/wiki/John_Dickinson "John Dickinson") and
completed by June 17, 1776, at the latest, declared "The name of this
Confederation shall be the 'United States of America'".[45] The final version
of the Articles sent to the states for ratification in late 1777 contains the
sentence "The Stile of this Confederacy shall be 'The United States of
America'".[46] In June 1776, [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas
Jefferson") wrote the phrase "UNITED STATES OF AMERICA" in all capitalized
letters in the headline of his "original Rough draught" of the [Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence").[45] This draft of the document did not surface
until June 21, 1776, and it is unclear whether it was written before or after
Dickinson used the term in his June 17 draft of the Articles of
Confederation.[45]

The short form "United States" is also standard. Other common forms are the
"U.S.", the "USA", and "America". Colloquial names are the "U.S. of A." and,
internationally, the "States". "[Columbia](/wiki/Columbia_\(name\) "Columbia
\(name\)")", a name popular in poetry and songs of the late 18th century,
derives its origin from [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus
"Christopher Columbus"); it appears in the name "[District of
Columbia](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.")".[47]

The phrase "United States" was originally plural, a description of a
collection of independent states—e.g., "the United States are"—including in
the [Thirteenth Amendment to the United States
Constitution](/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution"), ratified in
1865.[48] The singular form—e.g., "the United States is"—became popular after
the end of the American Civil War. The singular form is now standard; the
plural form is retained in the idiom "these United States". The difference is
more significant than usage; it is a difference between a collection of states
and a unit.[49]

A citizen of the United States is an "[American](/wiki/Americans
"Americans")". "United States", "American" and "U.S." refer to the country
adjectivally ("American values", "U.S. forces"). In English, the word
"[American](/wiki/American_\(word\) "American \(word\)")" rarely refers to
topics or subjects not connected with the United States.[50]

States](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States "History of the United States"),

"Timeline of United States history"), [American business
history](/wiki/American_business_history "American business history"),
[Economic history of the United
States](/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_United_States "Economic history of the

States](/wiki/Labor_history_of_the_United_States "Labor history of the United
