### Indigenous peoples and pre-Columbian history

Further information: [Pre-Columbian era](/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era "Pre-
Columbian era") and [Colonial history of the United
States](/wiki/Colonial_history_of_the_United_States "Colonial history of the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Chromesun_kincaid_site_01.jpg/220px-
Chromesun_kincaid_site_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chromesun_kincaid_site_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chromesun_kincaid_site_01.jpg "Enlarge")

Artist's re-creation of the [Kincaid
Site](/wiki/Kincaid_Mounds_State_Historic_Site "Kincaid Mounds State Historic
Site") from the prehistoric Mississippian culture, as it may have looked[51]

The [first inhabitants of North America](/wiki/Settlement_of_the_Americas
"Settlement of the Americas") migrated from [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia")
by way of the [Bering land bridge](/wiki/Beringia "Beringia") and arrived at
least 15,000 years ago, though increasing evidence suggests an even earlier
arrival.[52] After crossing the land bridge, the first Americans moved
southward, either along the Pacific coast[53][54] or through an interior ice-
free corridor between the Cordilleran and Laurentide ice sheets.[55] The
[Clovis culture](/wiki/Clovis_culture "Clovis culture") appeared around 11,000
BC, and it is considered to be an ancestor of most of the later indigenous
cultures of the Americas.[56] While the Clovis culture was thought, throughout
the late 20th century, to represent the first human settlement of the
Americas,[57] in recent years consensus has changed in recognition of pre-
Clovis cultures.[58]

Over time, indigenous cultures in North America grew increasingly complex, and
some, such as the [pre-Columbian](/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era "Pre-Columbian era")
[Mississippian culture](/wiki/Mississippian_culture "Mississippian culture")
in the southeast, developed advanced agriculture, grand architecture, and
state-level societies.[59] From approximately 800 to 1600 AD[60] the
Mississippian culture flourished, and its largest city [Cahokia](/wiki/Cahokia
"Cahokia") is considered the largest, most complex pre-Columbian
[archaeological site](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") in the modern-day
United States.[61] In the southern [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great
Lakes") region, the [Iroquois Confederacy](/wiki/Iroquois_Confederacy
"Iroquois Confederacy") (Haudenosaunee) was established at some point between
the twelfth[62] and fifteenth centuries,[63] lasting until the end of the
Revolutionary War.[64]

The date of the first settlements of the [Hawaiian
Islands](/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands "Hawaiian Islands") is a topic of continuing
debate.[65] [Archaeological](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") evidence seems
to indicate a settlement as early as 124 AD.[66] During his [third and final
voyage](/wiki/James_Cook#Third_voyage_.281776.E2.80.9379.29 "James Cook"),
[Captain James Cook](/wiki/Captain_James_Cook "Captain James Cook") became the
first European to begin formal contact with Hawaii.[67] After his initial
landfall in January 1778 at [Waimea](/wiki/Waimea,_Kauai_County,_Hawaii
"Waimea, Kauai County, Hawaii") harbour, [Kauai](/wiki/Kauai "Kauai"), Cook
named the [archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago") the "Sandwich
Islands" after the [fourth Earl of
Sandwich](/wiki/John_Montagu,_4th_Earl_of_Sandwich "John Montagu, 4th Earl of
Sandwich")—the acting [First Lord of the
Admiralty](/wiki/Lords_Commissioners_of_the_Admiralty "Lords Commissioners of
the Admiralty") of the British [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal
Navy").[68]

### European settlements

Further information: [European colonization of the
Americas](/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas "European colonization
of the Americas") and [Thirteen Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen
Colonies")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/View_of_St._Augustine_FL_at_intersection_of_Cathedral_Pl_and_Charlotte_St_20160707_1.jpg/220px-
View_of_St._Augustine_FL_at_intersection_of_Cathedral_Pl_and_Charlotte_St_20160707_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_of_St._Augustine_FL_at_intersection_of_Cathedral_Pl_and_Charlotte_St_20160707_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:View_of_St._Augustine_FL_at_intersection_of_Cathedral_Pl_and_Charlotte_St_20160707_1.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Saint Augustine, Florida](/wiki/Saint_Augustine,_Florida "Saint Augustine,
Florida"), the oldest continuously occupied European-established settlement in
the continental United States (1565)[69]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/The_Mayflower_Compact_1620_cph.3g07155.jpg/220px-
The_Mayflower_Compact_1620_cph.3g07155.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Mayflower_Compact_1620_cph.3g07155.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Mayflower_Compact_1620_cph.3g07155.jpg "Enlarge")

_The[Mayflower Compact](/wiki/Mayflower_Compact "Mayflower Compact"), 1620_ by
[Jean Leon Gerome Ferris](/wiki/Jean_Leon_Gerome_Ferris "Jean Leon Gerome
Ferris")

After Spain sent [Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher Columbus")
[on his first voyage](/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus#First_voyage
"Voyages of Christopher Columbus") to the [New World](/wiki/New_World "New
World") in 1492, other explorers followed. The first Europeans to arrive in
territory of the modern United States were Spanish
[conquistadors](/wiki/Conquistador "Conquistador") such as [Juan Ponce de
León](/wiki/Juan_Ponce_de_Le%C3%B3n "Juan Ponce de León"), who made his first
visit to Florida in 1513; however, if [unincorporated
territories](/wiki/Unincorporated_territories_of_the_United_States
"Unincorporated territories of the United States") are accounted for, then
credit would go to [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus
"Christopher Columbus") who landed in [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto
Rico") on his [1493
voyage](/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus#Second_voyage "Voyages of
Christopher Columbus"). Spanish set up the first settlements in Florida and
New Mexico such as [Saint Augustine](/wiki/St._Augustine,_Florida "St.
Augustine, Florida")[69] and [Santa Fe](/wiki/Santa_Fe_\(New_Mexico\) "Santa
Fe \(New Mexico\)"). The French established their own as well along the
[Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"). Successful
[English settlement](/wiki/English_overseas_possessions "English overseas
possessions") on the eastern coast of North America began with the Virginia
Colony in 1607 at [Jamestown](/wiki/Jamestown,_Virginia "Jamestown, Virginia")
and the [Pilgrims'](/wiki/Pilgrims_\(Plymouth_Colony\) "Pilgrims \(Plymouth
Colony\)") [Plymouth Colony](/wiki/Plymouth_Colony "Plymouth Colony") in 1620.
Many settlers were [dissenting Christian groups](/wiki/English_Dissenters
"English Dissenters") who came seeking [religious
freedom](/wiki/Freedom_of_religion "Freedom of religion"). The continent's
first elected legislative assembly, Virginia's [House of
Burgesses](/wiki/House_of_Burgesses "House of Burgesses") created in 1619, the
[Mayflower Compact](/wiki/Mayflower_Compact "Mayflower Compact"), signed by
the Pilgrims before disembarking, and the [Fundamental Orders of
Connecticut](/wiki/Fundamental_Orders_of_Connecticut "Fundamental Orders of
Connecticut"), established precedents for the pattern of representative self-
government and constitutionalism that would develop throughout the American
colonies.[70][71]

Most settlers in every colony were small farmers, but other industries
developed within a few decades as varied as the settlements. [Cash
crops](/wiki/Cash_crops "Cash crops") included tobacco, rice and wheat.
Extraction industries grew up in furs, fishing and lumber. Manufacturers
produced rum and ships, and by the late colonial period Americans were
producing one-seventh of the world's iron supply.[72] Cities eventually dotted
the coast to support local economies and serve as trade hubs. English
colonists were supplemented by waves of [Scotch-Irish](/wiki/Scotch-
Irish_American "Scotch-Irish American") and other groups. As coastal land grew
more expensive, freed [indentured servants](/wiki/Indentured_servitude
"Indentured servitude") pushed further west.[73]

A large-scale slave trade with English privateers was begun.[74] The life
expectancy of slaves was much higher in North America than further south,
because of less disease and better food and treatment, leading to a rapid
increase in the numbers of slaves.[75][76] Colonial society was largely
divided over the religious and moral implications of slavery and colonies
passed acts for and against the practice.[77][78] But by the turn of the 18th
century, African slaves were replacing indentured servants for cash crop
labor, especially in southern regions.[79]

With the British colonization of [Georgia](/wiki/Province_of_Georgia "Province
of Georgia") in 1732, the [13 colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen
Colonies") that would become the United States of America were
established.[80] All had local governments with elections open to most free
men, with a growing devotion to the ancient [rights of
Englishmen](/wiki/Rights_of_Englishmen "Rights of Englishmen") and a sense of
self-government stimulating support for republicanism.[81] With extremely high
birth rates, low death rates, and steady settlement, the colonial population
grew rapidly. Relatively small Native American populations were eclipsed.[82]
The [Christian revivalist](/wiki/Christian_revival "Christian revival")
movement of the 1730s and 1740s known as the [Great
Awakening](/wiki/First_Great_Awakening "First Great Awakening") fueled
interest in both religion and religious liberty.[83]

During the [Seven Years' War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War") (in
America, known as the [French and Indian War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War
"French and Indian War")), British forces seized Canada from the French, but
the [francophone](/wiki/French_language "French language") population remained
politically isolated from the southern colonies. Excluding the [Native
Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in
the United States"), who were being conquered and displaced, the 13 British
colonies had a population of over 2.1 million in 1770, about one-third that of
Britain. Despite continuing new arrivals, the rate of natural increase was
such that by the 1770s only a small minority of Americans had been born
overseas.[84] The colonies' distance from Britain had allowed the development
of self-government, but their success motivated monarchs to periodically seek
to reassert royal authority.[85]

In 1774 the [Spanish Navy](/wiki/Spanish_Navy "Spanish Navy") ship _Santiago_
, under [Juan Pérez](/wiki/Juan_Jos%C3%A9_P%C3%A9rez_Hern%C3%A1ndez "Juan José
Pérez Hernández") had entered and anchored in the inlet at [Nootka
Sound](/wiki/Nootka_Sound "Nootka Sound"). Although the Spanish did not land,
natives paddled to the ship to trade [furs](/wiki/Fur "Fur") for
[abalone](/wiki/Abalone "Abalone") shells from [California](/wiki/California
"California").[86] At the time, the Spanish were able to monopolize the trade
between [Asia](/wiki/Asia "Asia") and North America, granting limited licenses
to the [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal"). When the
[Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians") began establishing a growing [fur
trading](/wiki/Fur_trading "Fur trading") system in [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska
"Alaska") the Spanish began to challenge the Russians, with Pérez's voyage
being the first of many to the [Pacific Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest
"Pacific Northwest").[87][fn 8]

After having arrived in the Hawaiian islands in 1778, Captain Cook sailed
north and then north-east to explore the west coast of North America north of
the Spanish settlements in [Alta California](/wiki/Alta_California "Alta
California"). He made landfall on the Oregon coast at approximately 44°30′
north latitude, naming his landing point [Cape
Foulweather](/wiki/Cape_Foulweather "Cape Foulweather"). Bad weather forced
his ships south to about [43° north](/wiki/43rd_parallel_north "43rd parallel
north") before they could begin their exploration of the coast northward.[89]
In March 1778, Cook landed on [Bligh Island](/wiki/Bligh_Island_\(Canada\)
"Bligh Island \(Canada\)") and named the inlet "King George's Sound". He
recorded that the native name was _Nutka_ or Nootka, apparently
misunderstanding his conversations at _[Friendly
Cove/Yuquot](/wiki/Yuquot,_British_Columbia "Yuquot, British Columbia")_ ; his
informant may have been explaining that he was on an island (_itchme nutka_ ,
a place you can "go around"). There may also have been confusion with _[Nuu-
chah-nulth](/wiki/Nuu-chah-nulth_people "Nuu-chah-nulth people")_ , the
natives' autonym (name for themselves). It may also have simply been based on
Cook’s mispronunciation of Yuquot, the native name of the place.[90]

#### Effects on and interaction with native populations

Further information: [American Indian Wars](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars
"American Indian Wars"), [Population history of indigenous peoples of the
Americas](/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas
"Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas"), and [James
Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James Cook")

With the progress of European colonization in the territories of the
contemporary United States, the [Native
Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in
the United States") were often [conquered and
displaced](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars "American Indian Wars").[91] The [native
population of America
declined](/wiki/Population_history_of_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas
"Population history of indigenous peoples of the Americas") after Europeans
arrived, and for various reasons, primarily diseases such as
[smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox "Smallpox") and [measles](/wiki/Measles "Measles").
Violence was not a significant factor in the overall decline among [Native
Americans](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas"), though conflict among themselves and with Europeans affected
specific tribes and various colonial settlements.[92][93][94][95][96][97]

In the early days of colonization, many European settlers were subject to food
shortages, disease, and attacks from Native Americans. Native Americans were
also often at war with neighboring tribes and allied with Europeans in their
colonial wars. At the same time, however, many natives and settlers came to
depend on each other. Settlers traded for food and animal pelts, natives for
guns, ammunition and other European wares.[98] Natives taught many settlers
where, when and how to cultivate corn, beans and squash. European missionaries
and others felt it was important to "civilize" the Native Americans and urged
them to adopt European agricultural techniques and lifestyles.[99][100]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg/200px-
Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg "Enlarge")

_Death of Captain Cook_ by [Johann Zoffany](/wiki/Johann_Zoffany "Johann
Zoffany") (1795)

Captain James Cook's last voyage included sailing along the coast of North
America and Alaska searching for a [Northwest Passage](/wiki/Northwest_Passage
"Northwest Passage") for approximately nine months. He returned to the Hawaii
to resupply, initially exploring the coasts of [Maui](/wiki/Maui "Maui") and
the [big island](/wiki/Hawaii_Island "Hawaii Island"), trading with locals and
then making anchor at [Kealakekua Bay](/wiki/Kealakekua_Bay "Kealakekua Bay")
in January 1779. When his ships and company left the islands, a ship's mast
broke in bad weather, forcing them to return in mid-February. Cook would be
killed days later.[101] [fn 9][fn 10]

### Independence and expansion (1776–1865)

Further information: [American Revolutionary
War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), [United
States Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence"), [American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution
"American Revolution"), and [Territorial evolution of the United
States](/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_the_United_States "Territorial
evolution of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg/220px-
Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg)](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Independence_\(1819\),_by_John_Trumbull.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Independence_\(1819\),_by_John_Trumbull.jpg
"Enlarge")

_[Declaration of Independence](/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_\(Trumbull\)
"Declaration of Independence \(Trumbull\)")_ by [John
Trumbull](/wiki/John_Trumbull "John Trumbull")

The American Revolutionary War was the first successful colonial war of
independence against a European power. Americans had developed an ideology of
"[republicanism](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism in
the United States")" asserting that government rested on the will of the
people as expressed in their local legislatures. They demanded their [rights
as Englishmen](/wiki/Rights_of_Englishmen "Rights of Englishmen") and "no
taxation without representation". The British insisted on administering the
empire through Parliament, and [the conflict](/wiki/American_Revolution
"American Revolution") escalated into war.[114]

Following the passage of the [Lee Resolution](/wiki/Lee_Resolution "Lee
Resolution"), on July 2, 1776, which was the actual vote for independence, the
[Second Continental Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second
Continental Congress") adopted the [Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence") on July 4, which proclaimed, in a long preamble,
that humanity is created equal in their unalienable rights and that those
rights were not being protected by [Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain"), and
declared, in the words of the resolution, that the [Thirteen
Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") were independent states
and had no allegiance to the British crown in the United States. The fourth
day of July is celebrated annually as [Independence
Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_\(United_States\) "Independence Day \(United
States\)").[115] The Second Continental Congress declared on September 9
"where, heretofore, the words 'United Colonies' have been used, the stile be
altered for the future to the 'United States' ".[116] In 1777, the [Articles
of Confederation](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation")
established a weak government that operated until 1789.[115]

Britain recognized the independence of the United States following their
[defeat at Yorktown](/wiki/Siege_of_Yorktown "Siege of Yorktown") in
1781.[117] In the [peace treaty of 1783](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1783\)
"Treaty of Paris \(1783\)"), American sovereignty was recognized from the
Atlantic coast west to the Mississippi River. Nationalists led the
[Philadelphia Convention](/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_\(United_States\)
"Constitutional Convention \(United States\)") of 1787 in writing the [United
States Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
Constitution"),
[ratified](/wiki/Ratification_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Ratification
of the United States Constitution") in state conventions in 1788. The federal
government was reorganized into three branches, on the principle of creating
salutary checks and balances, in 1789. George Washington, who had led the
revolutionary army to victory, was the first
[president](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") elected under the new constitution. The [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights"),
forbidding federal restriction of [personal
freedoms](/wiki/Natural_and_legal_rights "Natural and legal rights") and
guaranteeing a range of legal protections, was adopted in 1791.[118]

Although the federal government criminalized the international slave trade in
1808, after 1820, cultivation of the highly profitable cotton crop exploded in
the [Deep South](/wiki/Deep_South "Deep South"), and along with it, the slave
population.[119][120][121] The [Second Great
Awakening](/wiki/Second_Great_Awakening "Second Great Awakening"), especially
1800–1840, converted millions to [evangelical](/wiki/Evangelicalism
"Evangelicalism") Protestantism. In the North, it energized multiple social
reform movements, including
[abolitionism](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the
United States");[122] in the South, Methodists and Baptists proselytized among
slave populations.[123]

Americans' eagerness to [expand
westward](/wiki/United_States_territorial_acquisitions "United States
territorial acquisitions") prompted a long series of [American Indian
Wars](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars "American Indian Wars").[124] The [Louisiana
Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase "Louisiana Purchase") of French-claimed
territory in 1803 almost doubled the nation's area.[125] The [War of
1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"), declared against Britain over various
grievances and fought to a draw, strengthened U.S. nationalism.[126] A series
of military incursions into Florida led [Spain to
cede](/wiki/Adams%E2%80%93On%C3%ADs_Treaty "Adams–Onís Treaty") it and other
Gulf Coast territory in 1819.[127] Expansion was aided by [steam
power](/wiki/Steam_engine "Steam engine"), when [steamboats](/wiki/Steamboats
"Steamboats") began traveling along America's large water systems, which were
connected by new [canals](/wiki/Canal "Canal"), such as the
[Erie](/wiki/Erie_Canal "Erie Canal") and the
[I&M](/wiki/Illinois_and_Michigan_Canal "Illinois and Michigan Canal"); then,
even faster railroads began their stretch across the nation's land.[128]

From 1820 to 1850, [Jacksonian democracy](/wiki/Jacksonian_democracy
"Jacksonian democracy") began a set of reforms which included wider white male
suffrage; it led to the rise of the [Second Party
System](/wiki/Second_Party_System "Second Party System") of Democrats and
Whigs as the dominant parties from 1828 to 1854. The [Trail of
Tears](/wiki/Trail_of_Tears "Trail of Tears") in the 1830s exemplified the
[Indian removal policy](/wiki/Indian_Removal_Act "Indian Removal Act") that
resettled Indians into the west on [Indian
reservations](/wiki/Indian_reservations "Indian reservations"). The U.S.
annexed the [Republic of Texas](/wiki/Republic_of_Texas "Republic of Texas")
in 1845 during a period of expansionist [Manifest
destiny](/wiki/Manifest_destiny "Manifest destiny").[129] The 1846 [Oregon
Treaty](/wiki/Oregon_Treaty "Oregon Treaty") with Britain led to U.S. control
of the present-day [American Northwest](/wiki/Northwestern_United_States
"Northwestern United States").[130] Victory in the [Mexican–American
War](/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War "Mexican–American War") resulted in
the 1848 [Mexican Cession](/wiki/Mexican_Cession "Mexican Cession") of
California and much of the present-day American Southwest.[131]

The [California Gold Rush](/wiki/California_Gold_Rush "California Gold Rush")
of 1848–49 spurred western migration and the creation of additional western
states.[132] After the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American
Civil War"), new transcontinental
[railways](/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_United_States#History "Rail
transportation in the United States") made relocation easier for settlers,
expanded internal trade and increased conflicts with Native Americans.[133]
Over a half-century, the loss of the [American bison](/wiki/American_bison
"American bison") (sometimes called "buffalo") was an existential blow to many
[Plains Indians](/wiki/Plains_Indians "Plains Indians") cultures.[134] In
1869, a new [Peace
Policy](/wiki/Presidency_of_Ulysses_S._Grant#Indian_affairs_and_human_rights
"Presidency of Ulysses S. Grant") sought to protect Native-Americans from
abuses, avoid further war, and secure their eventual U.S. citizenship,
although conflicts, including several of the largest Indian Wars, continued
throughout the West into the 1900s.[135]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-
below.jpg/220px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg)](/wiki/File:Liberty-statue-
from-below.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Statue of Liberty](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty") in [New
York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), dedicated in 1886, is a
symbol of the United States as well as its ideals of freedom, democracy and
opportunity.[136]

### Civil War and Reconstruction Era

Further information: [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American
Civil War") and [Reconstruction Era](/wiki/Reconstruction_Era "Reconstruction
Era")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Thure_de_Thulstrup_-
_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-
_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Thure_de_Thulstrup_-
_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-
_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thure_de_Thulstrup_-
_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-
_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-
_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

_The[Battle of Gettysburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg "Battle of Gettysburg")_
by [Thure de Thulstrup](/wiki/Thure_de_Thulstrup "Thure de Thulstrup")

Differences of opinion over social order between northern and southern states
in early United States society, particularly regarding [the
slavery](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States") of
[Africans](/wiki/Africans "Africans") and [African
Americans](/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans"), ultimately led to the
[American Civil War](/wiki/Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War "Origins of the
American Civil War").[137] Initially, states entering the Union alternated
between [slave and free states](/wiki/Slave_states_and_free_states "Slave
states and free states"), keeping a sectional balance in the Senate, while
free states outstripped slave states in population and in the House of
Representatives. But with additional western territory and more free-soil
states, tensions between slave and free states mounted with arguments over
federalism and disposition of the territories, whether and how to expand or
restrict slavery.[138]

With the 1860 election of [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham
Lincoln"), the first president from the largely anti-slavery [Republican
Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)"), conventions in thirteen slave states ultimately declared secession
and formed the [Confederate States of
America](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of America"),
while the federal government maintained that secession was illegal.[138] The
ensuing war was at first for Union, then after 1863 as casualties mounted and
Lincoln delivered his [Emancipation
Proclamation](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation Proclamation"), a
second war aim became abolition of slavery. The war remains the deadliest
military conflict in American history, resulting in the deaths of
approximately 618,000 soldiers as well as many civilians.[139]

Following the [Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American
Civil War\)") victory in 1865, [three
amendments](/wiki/Reconstruction_Amendments "Reconstruction Amendments") were
added to the U.S. Constitution: the [Thirteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") prohibited slavery,
the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") provided citizenship
to the nearly four million [African Americans](/wiki/African_American "African
American") who had been slaves,[140] and the [Fifteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fifteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") ensured that they had
the right to vote. The war and its resolution led to a substantial increase in
[federal power](/wiki/Federalism_in_the_United_States "Federalism in the
United States")[141] aimed at reintegrating and rebuilding the Southern states
while ensuring the rights of the newly freed slaves.

Southern white conservatives, calling themselves "[Redeemers](/wiki/Redeemers
"Redeemers")" took control after the end of Reconstruction. By the 1890–1910
period [Jim Crow laws](/wiki/Jim_Crow_laws "Jim Crow laws")
[disenfranchised](/wiki/Disenfranchisement_after_the_Reconstruction_Era
"Disenfranchisement after the Reconstruction Era") most blacks and some poor
whites. Blacks faced [racial
segregation](/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States "Racial segregation
in the United States"), especially in the South.[142] Racial minorities
occasionally experienced [vigilante
violence](/wiki/Lynching_in_the_United_States "Lynching in the United
States").[143]

### Further immigration, expansion, and industrialization

Main articles: [Economic history of the United
States](/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_United_States "Economic history of the
United States") and [Technological and industrial history of the United
States](/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States
"Technological and industrial history of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Ellis_island_1902.jpg/220px-
Ellis_island_1902.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ellis_island_1902.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ellis_island_1902.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ellis Island](/wiki/Ellis_Island "Ellis Island"), in New York City, was a
major gateway for European
[immigration](/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the
United States")[144]

In the North, urbanization and an unprecedented [influx of
immigrants](/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States#History "Immigration to the
United States") from [Southern](/wiki/Southern_Europe "Southern Europe") and
[Eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe") supplied a surplus of
labor for the country's industrialization and transformed its culture.[145]
National infrastructure including
[telegraph](/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Telegraph "First Transcontinental
Telegraph") and [transcontinental
railroads](/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad "First Transcontinental
Railroad") spurred economic growth and greater settlement and development of
the [American Old West](/wiki/American_frontier "American frontier"). The
later invention of [electric light](/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb
"Incandescent light bulb") and the [telephone](/wiki/Telephone "Telephone")
would also affect communication and urban life.[146]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/American_Empire1.PNG/250px-
American_Empire1.PNG)](/wiki/File:American_Empire1.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:American_Empire1.PNG "Enlarge")

United States and its territories at their greatest extent from 1898 to 1902

The end of the [Indian Wars](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars "American Indian
Wars") further expanded acreage under mechanical cultivation, increasing
surpluses for international markets.[147] Mainland expansion was completed by
the [purchase of Alaska](/wiki/Alaska_Purchase "Alaska Purchase") from
[Russia](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") in 1867.[148] In 1893, pro-
American elements in Hawaii
[overthrew](/wiki/Overthrow_of_the_Kingdom_of_Hawaii "Overthrow of the Kingdom
of Hawaii") the [monarchy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hawaii "Kingdom of Hawaii") and
formed the [Republic of Hawaii](/wiki/Republic_of_Hawaii "Republic of
Hawaii"), which the U.S. [annexed](/wiki/Territory_of_Hawaii "Territory of
Hawaii") in 1898. [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"),
[Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"), and the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines
"Philippines") were ceded by Spain in the same year, following the
[Spanish–American War](/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War "Spanish–American
War").[149]

[Rapid economic development](/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age") during the late
19th and early 20th centuries fostered the rise of many prominent
industrialists. [Tycoons](/wiki/Business_magnate "Business magnate") like
[Cornelius Vanderbilt](/wiki/Cornelius_Vanderbilt "Cornelius Vanderbilt"),
[John D. Rockefeller](/wiki/John_D._Rockefeller "John D. Rockefeller"), and
[Andrew Carnegie](/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie") led the nation's
progress in [railroad](/wiki/Railways "Railways"),
[petroleum](/wiki/Petroleum_industry "Petroleum industry"), and
[steel](/wiki/History_of_the_steel_industry "History of the steel industry")
industries. Banking became a major part of the economy, with [J. P.
Morgan](/wiki/J._P._Morgan "J. P. Morgan") playing a notable role.
[Edison](/wiki/Thomas_Edison "Thomas Edison") and [Tesla](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla
"Nikola Tesla") undertook the widespread distribution of electricity to
industry, homes, and for street lighting. [Henry Ford](/wiki/Henry_Ford "Henry
Ford") revolutionized the [automotive industry](/wiki/Automotive_industry
"Automotive industry"). The American economy boomed, becoming the world's
largest, and the United States achieved [great power](/wiki/Great_power "Great
power") status.[150] These dramatic changes were accompanied by social unrest
and the rise of [populist](/wiki/People%27s_Party_\(United_States\) "People's
Party \(United States\)"),
[socialist](/wiki/History_of_the_socialist_movement_in_the_United_States
"History of the socialist movement in the United States"), and
[anarchist](/wiki/Anarchism_in_the_United_States "Anarchism in the United
States") movements.[151] This period eventually ended with the advent of the
[Progressive Era](/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive Era"), which saw
significant reforms in many societal areas, including [women's
suffrage](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage "Women's suffrage"), [alcohol
prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition in the United
States"), regulation of consumer goods, greater [antitrust
measures](/wiki/United_States_antitrust_law "United States antitrust law") to
ensure competition and attention to worker conditions.[152][153][154]

### World War I, Great Depression, and World War II

Further information: [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression"), and [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg/220px-
Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg)](/wiki/File:Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg "Enlarge")

Crowd gathering on [Wall Street](/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall Street") after the
1929 crash

The United States remained neutral from the outbreak of [World War
I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), in 1914, until 1917 when it joined the
war as an "associated power", alongside the formal [Allies of World War
I](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I"), helping to turn the
tide against the [Central Powers](/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers"). In
1919, President [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson") took a
leading diplomatic role at the [Paris Peace
Conference](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919 "Paris Peace Conference, 1919")
and advocated strongly for the U.S. to join the [League of
Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"). However, the Senate
refused to approve this, and did not ratify the [Treaty of
Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") that
established the League of Nations.[155]

In 1920, the women's rights movement won passage of a [constitutional
amendment](/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") granting [women's
suffrage](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_States "Women's suffrage in
the United States").[156] The 1920s and 1930s saw the rise of
[radio](/wiki/Radio "Radio") for [mass communication](/wiki/Mass_communication
"Mass communication") and the invention of early [television](/wiki/Television
"Television").[157] The prosperity of the [Roaring
Twenties](/wiki/Roaring_Twenties "Roaring Twenties") ended with the [Wall
Street Crash of 1929](/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall Street Crash of
1929") and the onset of the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in
the United States"). After his election as president in 1932, [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") responded with
the [New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal"), which included the establishment of
the [Social Security](/wiki/Social_Security_\(United_States\) "Social Security
\(United States\)") system.[158] The [Great
Migration](/wiki/Great_Migration_\(African_American\) "Great Migration
\(African American\)") of millions of African Americans out of the American
South began before World War I and extended through the 1960s;[159] whereas
the [Dust Bowl](/wiki/Dust_Bowl "Dust Bowl") of the mid-1930s impoverished
many farming communities and spurred a new wave of western migration.[160]

At first effectively neutral during [World War
II](/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II "Military
history of the United States during World War II") while Germany conquered
much of continental Europe, the United States began supplying material to the
[Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") in March 1941
through the [Lend-Lease](/wiki/Lend-Lease "Lend-Lease") program. On December
7, 1941, the [Empire of Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
launched a surprise [attack on Pearl Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor
"Attack on Pearl Harbor"), prompting the United States to join the Allies
against the [Axis powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers").[161] During the
war, the United States was referred as one of the "[Four
Policemen](/wiki/Four_Policemen "Four Policemen")"[162] of Allies power who
met to plan the postwar world, along with Britain, the Soviet Union and
China.[163][164] Though the nation lost more than 400,000 soldiers,[165] it
emerged [relatively
undamaged](/wiki/World_War_II_casualties#Human_losses_by_country "World War II
casualties") from the war with even greater economic and military
influence.[166]

The United States played a leading role in the [Bretton
Woods](/wiki/Bretton_Woods_Conference "Bretton Woods Conference") and
[Yalta](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference") conferences with the United
Kingdom, the Soviet Union and other Allies, which signed agreements on new
international financial institutions and Europe's postwar reorganization. As
an [Allied victory was won in Europe](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in
Europe Day"), a 1945 [international
conference](/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_International_Organization
"United Nations Conference on International Organization") held in [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") produced the [United Nations
Charter](/wiki/United_Nations_Charter "United Nations Charter"), which became
active after the war.[167] The United States developed the [first nuclear
weapons](/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project") and used them on Japan
[in the cities of Hiroshima and
Nagasaki](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of
Hiroshima and Nagasaki"); causing the Japanese to
[surrender](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of Japan") on September 2,
ending World War II.[168][169] Parades and celebrations followed in what is
known as [Victory Day](/wiki/Victory_Day_\(United_States\) "Victory Day
\(United States\)"), or V-J Day.[170]

### Cold War and civil rights era

Main articles: [History of the United States
(1945–64)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1945%E2%80%9364\) "History of
the United States \(1945–64\)"), [History of the United States
(1964–80)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1964%E2%80%9380\) "History of
the United States \(1964–80\)"), and [History of the United States
(1980–91)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1980%E2%80%9391\) "History of
the United States \(1980–91\)")

Further information: [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), [Civil Rights
Movement](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement "Civil Rights Movement"), [War on
Poverty](/wiki/War_on_Poverty "War on Poverty"), [Space Race](/wiki/Space_Race
"Space Race"), and [Reaganomics](/wiki/Reaganomics "Reaganomics")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/ReaganBerlinWall.jpg/220px-
ReaganBerlinWall.jpg)](/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg "Enlarge")

U.S. President [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") at his
"[Tear down this wall!](/wiki/Tear_down_this_wall! "Tear down this wall!")"
speech in [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), Germany on June 12, 1987.[171]

After World War II the United States and the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union
"Soviet Union") jockeyed for power during what became known as the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), driven by an ideological divide between
[capitalism](/wiki/Capitalism "Capitalism") and [communism](/wiki/Communism
"Communism")[172] and, according to the school of
[geopolitics](/wiki/Geopolitics "Geopolitics"), a divide between the maritime
Atlantic and the continental Eurasian camps. They dominated the military
affairs of [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), with the U.S. and its
[NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") allies on one side and the USSR and its [Warsaw
Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact "Warsaw Pact") allies on the other. The U.S.
[developed a policy of containment](/wiki/Containment "Containment") towards
the expansion of communist influence. While the U.S. and Soviet Union engaged
in [proxy wars](/wiki/Proxy_war "Proxy war") and developed powerful nuclear
arsenals, the two countries avoided direct military conflict.

The United States often opposed [Third World](/wiki/Third_World "Third World")
movements that it viewed as Soviet-sponsored. American troops fought communist
[Chinese](/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army "People's Liberation Army") and
[North Korean](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") forces in the [Korean
War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") of 1950–53.[173] The Soviet Union's 1957
launch of the [first artificial satellite](/wiki/Sputnik_1 "Sputnik 1") and
its 1961 launch of the [first manned spaceflight](/wiki/Vostok_1 "Vostok 1")
initiated a "[Space Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race")" in which the United
States became the first nation to [land a man on the moon](/wiki/Apollo_11
"Apollo 11") in 1969.[173] A proxy war in Southeast Asia eventually evolved
into full American participation, as the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War
"Vietnam War").

At home, the U.S. experienced [sustained economic
expansion](/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion "Post–World War
II economic expansion") and a [rapid growth of its
population](/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom "Post–World War II baby
boom") and middle class. Construction of an [Interstate Highway
System](/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System "Interstate Highway System")
transformed the nation's infrastructure over the following decades. Millions
moved from farms and [inner cities](/wiki/Inner_city "Inner city") to large
[suburban](/wiki/Suburb "Suburb") housing developments.[174][175] In 1959
[Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") became the 50th and last U.S. state added to
the country.[176] The growing [Civil Rights
Movement](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement "Civil Rights Movement") used
[nonviolence](/wiki/Nonviolence "Nonviolence") to confront segregation and
discrimination, with [Martin Luther King Jr.](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.
"Martin Luther King Jr.") becoming a prominent leader and figurehead. A
combination of court decisions and legislation, culminating in the [Civil
Rights Act of 1968](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1968 "Civil Rights Act of
1968"), sought to end racial discrimination.[177][178][179] Meanwhile, a
[counterculture movement](/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s "Counterculture of
the 1960s") grew which was fueled by [opposition to the Vietnam
war](/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War
"Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War"), [black
nationalism](/wiki/Black_nationalism "Black nationalism"), and the [sexual
revolution](/wiki/Sexual_revolution "Sexual revolution").

The launch of a "[War on Poverty](/wiki/War_on_Poverty "War on Poverty")"
expanded entitlements and welfare spending, including the creation of
[Medicare](/wiki/Medicare_\(United_States\) "Medicare \(United States\)") and
[Medicaid](/wiki/Medicaid "Medicaid"), two programs that provide health
coverage to the elderly and poor, respectively, and the [means-
tested](/wiki/Means-tested "Means-tested") [Food Stamp
Program](/wiki/Food_Stamp_Program "Food Stamp Program") and [Aid to Families
with Dependent Children](/wiki/Aid_to_Families_with_Dependent_Children "Aid to
Families with Dependent Children").[180]

The 1970s and early 1980s saw the onset of [stagflation](/wiki/Stagflation
"Stagflation"). After his election in 1980, President [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") responded to economic stagnation
with [free-market oriented reforms](/wiki/Reaganomics "Reaganomics").
Following the collapse of [détente](/wiki/D%C3%A9tente "Détente"), he
abandoned "containment" and initiated the more aggressive
"[rollback](/wiki/Rollback "Rollback")" strategy towards the
USSR.[181][182][183][184][185] After a surge in female labor participation
over the previous decade, by 1985 the majority of women aged 16 and over were
employed.[186]

The late 1980s brought a "[thaw](/wiki/Cold_War_\(1985%E2%80%9391\) "Cold War
\(1985–91\)")" in relations with the USSR, and [its
collapse](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet
Union") in 1991 finally ended the Cold War.[187][188][189][190] This brought
about [unipolarity](/wiki/Unipolarity "Unipolarity")[191] with the U.S.
unchallenged as the world's dominant superpower. The concept of [Pax
Americana](/wiki/Pax_Americana "Pax Americana"), which had appeared in the
post-World War II period, gained wide popularity as a term for the post-Cold
War [new world order.](/wiki/New_world_order_\(politics\) "New world order
\(politics\)")

### Contemporary history

Main articles: [History of the United States
(1991–2008)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1991%E2%80%932008\) "History
of the United States \(1991–2008\)") and [History of the United States
(2008–present)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(2008%E2%80%93present\)
"History of the United States \(2008–present\)")

Further information: [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War"), [September 11
attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"), [War on
Terror](/wiki/War_on_Terror "War on Terror"), [2008 financial
crisis](/wiki/2008_financial_crisis "2008 financial crisis"), and [Affordable
Care Act](/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act "Affordable Care Act")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/240px-
WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)](/wiki/File:WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)

The [World Trade Center](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_\(1973%E2%80%932001\) "World
Trade Center \(1973–2001\)") in [Lower Manhattan](/wiki/Lower_Manhattan "Lower
Manhattan") during the [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks
"September 11 attacks") in 2001

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/120px-
OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg)](/wiki/File:OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg)

[One World Trade Center](/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center "One World Trade
Center"), newly-built in its place

After the Cold War, the conflict in the Middle East triggered a crisis in
1990, when [Iraq](/wiki/Ba%27athist_Iraq "Ba'athist Iraq") under [Sadaam
Hussein](/wiki/Sadaam_Hussein "Sadaam Hussein") [invaded and attempted to
annex Kuwait](/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait "Invasion of Kuwait"), an ally of the
United States. Fearing that the instability would spread to other regions,
President [George H.W. Bush](/wiki/George_H.W._Bush "George H.W. Bush")
launched [Operation Desert Shield](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War"), a defensive
force buildup in Saudi Arabia, and [Operation Desert Storm](/wiki/Gulf_War
"Gulf War"), in a staging titled the Gulf War; waged by [coalition
forces](/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War "Coalition of the Gulf War") from 34
nations, led by the United States against Iraq ending in the successful
expulsion of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, restoring the former monarchy.[192]

Originating in [U.S. defense networks](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET"), the
[Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet") spread to international academic
networks, and then to the public in the 1990s, greatly affecting the global
economy, society, and culture.[193]

Due to the [dot-com boom](/wiki/Dot-com_boom "Dot-com boom"), stable monetary
policy under [Alan Greenspan](/wiki/Alan_Greenspan "Alan Greenspan"), and
[reduced social welfare
spending](/wiki/Personal_Responsibility_and_Work_Opportunity_Act "Personal
Responsibility and Work Opportunity Act"), the 1990s saw the [longest economic
expansion](/wiki/1990s_United_States_boom "1990s United States boom") in
modern U.S. history, ending in 2001.[194] Beginning in 1994, the U.S. entered
into the [North American Free Trade
Agreement](/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement "North American Free
Trade Agreement") (NAFTA), linking 450 million people producing $17 trillion
worth of goods and services. The goal of the agreement was to eliminate trade
and investment barriers among the U.S., Canada, and Mexico by January 1, 2008.
Trade among the three partners has soared since NAFTA went into force.[195]

On [September 11, 2001](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"),
[Al-Qaeda](/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-Qaeda") terrorists struck the [World Trade
Center](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_\(1973%E2%80%932001\) "World Trade Center
\(1973–2001\)") in New York City and [the Pentagon](/wiki/The_Pentagon "The
Pentagon") near Washington, D.C., killing nearly 3,000 people.[196] In
response, the United States launched the [War on Terror](/wiki/War_on_Terror
"War on Terror"), which included [war in
Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%932014\) "War in
Afghanistan \(2001–2014\)") and the 2003–11 [Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq
War").[197][198] In 2007, the Bush administration ordered a major [troop surge
in the Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War_troop_surge_of_2007 "Iraq War troop surge of
2007"),[199] which successfully reduced violence and led to greater stability
in the region.[200][201]

Government policy designed to promote affordable housing,[202] widespread
failures in corporate and regulatory governance,[203] and historically low
interest rates set by the Federal Reserve[204] led to the [mid-2000s housing
bubble](/wiki/United_States_housing_bubble "United States housing bubble"),
which culminated with the [2008 financial crisis](/wiki/2008_financial_crisis
"2008 financial crisis"), the largest economic contraction in the nation's
history since the Great Depression.[205] [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama
"Barack Obama"), the first [African American](/wiki/African_American "African
American")[206] and [multiracial](/wiki/Multiracial_American "Multiracial
American")[207] president, [was elected in
2008](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008 "United States
presidential election, 2008") amid the crisis,[208] and subsequently passed
[stimulus measures](/wiki/American_Reinvestment_and_Recovery_Act "American
Reinvestment and Recovery Act") and the [Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and
Consumer Protection Act](/wiki/Dodd-
Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act "Dodd-Frank Wall Street
Reform and Consumer Protection Act") in an attempt to mitigate its negative
effects and ensure there would not be a repeat of the crisis. The stimulus
facilitated infrastructure improvements[209] and a relative decline in
unemployment.[210] Dodd-Frank improved financial stability and consumer
protection,[211] although there is evidence it may have had a negative impact
on small banks.[212]

In 2010, the Obama administration passed the [Affordable Care
Act](/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient Protection and
Affordable Care Act"), which made the most sweeping reforms to the [nation's
healthcare system](/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States "Health care in the
United States") in nearly five decades, including
[mandates](/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act#Mandates "Patient
Protection and Affordable Care Act"), [subsidies](/wiki/Premium_tax_credit
"Premium tax credit") and [insurance
exchanges](/wiki/Health_insurance_marketplace "Health insurance marketplace").
The law caused a significant reduction in the number and percentage of people
without health insurance, with 24 million covered during 2016,[213] but
remains controversial due to its impact on healthcare costs, insurance
premiums, and economic performance.[214] Although the recession reached its
trough in June 2009, voters remained frustrated with the slow pace of the
economic recovery. The Republicans, who stood in opposition to Obama's
policies, won control of the House of Representatives with [a landslide in
2010](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2010 "United
States House of Representatives elections, 2010") and control of the Senate in
[2014](/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2014 "United States Senate
elections, 2014").[215]

American forces in Iraq were
[withdrawn](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_U.S._troops_from_Iraq "Withdrawal of U.S.
troops from Iraq") in large numbers in 2009 and 2010, and the war in the
region was declared formally over in December 2011.[216] The withdrawal caused
[an escalation of sectarian
insurgency](/wiki/Iraqi_insurgency_\(2011%E2%80%9313\) "Iraqi insurgency
\(2011–13\)"),[217] leading to the rise of the [Islamic State of Iraq and the
Levant](/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant "Islamic State of Iraq and
the Levant"), the successor of al-Qaeda in the region.[218] In 2014, Obama
announced a [restoration](/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Cuban_Thaw "United
States–Cuban Thaw") of full [diplomatic relations with
Cuba](/wiki/Cuba%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Cuba–United States
relations") for the first time since 1961.[_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_][219] The next year, the
United States as a member of the [P5+1](/wiki/P5%2B1 "P5+1") countries signed
the [Joint Comprehensive Plan of
Action](/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action "Joint Comprehensive Plan of
Action"), an agreement aimed to slow the development of [Iran's nuclear
program](/wiki/Nuclear_program_of_Iran "Nuclear program of Iran").[220]

## Geography, climate, and environment

Main articles: [Geography of the United
States](/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_States "Geography of the United
States"), [Climate of the United States](/wiki/Climate_of_the_United_States
"Climate of the United States"), and [Environment of the United
States](/wiki/Environment_of_the_United_States "Environment of the United
States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/USA-
satellite.jpg/220px-USA-satellite.jpg)](/wiki/File:USA-satellite.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USA-satellite.jpg "Enlarge")

A composite satellite image of the contiguous United States and surrounding
areas

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/US50states_koppen.svg/220px-
US50states_koppen.svg.png)](/wiki/File:US50states_koppen.svg)

[](/wiki/File:US50states_koppen.svg "Enlarge")

[Köppen climate classifications](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification
"Köppen climate classification")

The land area of the [contiguous United States](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States
"Contiguous United States") is 2,959,064 square miles (7,663,940.6 km2).
Alaska, separated from the contiguous United States by Canada, is the largest
state at 663,268 square miles (1,717,856.2 km2). [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii
"Hawaii"), occupying an archipelago in the central
[Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean"), southwest of North America, is
10,931 square miles (28,311 km2) in area. The populated territories of [Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), [American Samoa](/wiki/American_Samoa
"American Samoa"), [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"), [Northern Mariana
Islands](/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands "Northern Mariana Islands"), and [U.S.
Virgin Islands](/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin
Islands") together cover 9,185 square miles (23,789 km2).[221] Measured by
only land area, the United States is third in size behind Russia and China,
just ahead of Canada.[222]

The United States is the world's third- or fourth-[largest nation by total
area](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area "List of countries and
dependencies by area") (land and water), ranking behind Russia and Canada and
just above or below [China](/wiki/China "China"). The ranking varies depending
on how two territories disputed by China and [India](/wiki/India "India") are
counted and how the total size of the United States is measured: calculations
range from 3,676,486 square miles (9,522,055.0 km2)[223] to 3,717,813 square
miles (9,629,091.5 km2)[224] to 3,796,742 square miles (9,833,516.6 km2).[225]

The coastal plain of the [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean")
seaboard gives way further inland to [deciduous](/wiki/Deciduous "Deciduous")
forests and the rolling hills of the
[Piedmont](/wiki/Piedmont_\(United_States\) "Piedmont \(United
States\)").[226] The [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains
"Appalachian Mountains") divide the eastern seaboard from the [Great
Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") and the grasslands of the
[Midwest](/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern United States").[227] The
[Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River")–[Missouri
River](/wiki/Missouri_River "Missouri River"), the world's [fourth longest
river system](/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length "List of rivers by length"), runs
mainly north–south through the heart of the country. The flat, fertile
[prairie](/wiki/Prairie "Prairie") of the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains
"Great Plains") stretches to the west, interrupted by [a highland
region](/wiki/U.S._Interior_Highlands "U.S. Interior Highlands") in the
southeast.[227]

The [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"), at the western
edge of the Great Plains, extend north to south across the country, reaching
altitudes higher than 14,000 feet (4,300 m) in [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado
"Colorado").[228] Farther west are the rocky [Great Basin](/wiki/Great_Basin
"Great Basin") and deserts such as the [Chihuahua](/wiki/Chihuahuan_Desert
"Chihuahuan Desert") and [Mojave](/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert").[229]
The [Sierra Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)") and
[Cascade](/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade Range") mountain ranges run close to
the [Pacific coast](/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States "West Coast of the
United States"), both ranges reaching altitudes higher than 14,000 feet (4,300
m). The [lowest and highest points](/wiki/Extreme_points_of_the_United_States
"Extreme points of the United States") in the
[contiguous](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States") United
States are in the state of [California](/wiki/California "California"),[230]
and only about 84 miles (135 km) apart.[231] At an elevation of 20,310 feet
(6,190.5 m), Alaska's [Denali](/wiki/Denali "Denali") (Mount McKinley) is the
highest peak in the country and North America.[232] Active
[volcanoes](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano") are common throughout Alaska's
[Alexander](/wiki/Alexander_Archipelago "Alexander Archipelago") and [Aleutian
Islands](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands"), and Hawaii consists of
volcanic islands. The [supervolcano](/wiki/Supervolcano "Supervolcano")
underlying [Yellowstone National Park](/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park
"Yellowstone National Park") in the [Rockies](/wiki/Rockies "Rockies") is the
continent's largest volcanic feature.[233] The United States has the most
ecoregions out of any country in the world.[234]

The United States, with its large size and geographic variety, includes most
climate types. To the east of the [100th meridian](/wiki/100th_meridian_west
"100th meridian west"), the climate ranges from [humid
continental](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") in
the north to [humid subtropical](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid
subtropical climate") in the south.[235] The Great Plains west of the 100th
meridian are semi-arid. Much of the Western mountains have an [alpine
climate](/wiki/Alpine_climate "Alpine climate"). The climate is arid in the
Great Basin, desert in the Southwest,
[Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") in
[coastal California](/wiki/Coastal_California "Coastal California"), and
[oceanic](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") in coastal
[Oregon](/wiki/Oregon "Oregon") and [Washington](/wiki/Washington_\(state\)
"Washington \(state\)") and southern Alaska. Most of Alaska is subarctic or
polar. Hawaii and the southern tip of [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") are
tropical, as are the populated territories in the Caribbean and the
Pacific.[236] Extreme weather is not uncommon—the states bordering the [Gulf
of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") are prone to
[hurricanes](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone "Tropical cyclone"), and most of the
world's [tornadoes](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado") occur within the country, mainly
in [Tornado Alley](/wiki/Tornado_Alley "Tornado Alley") areas in the Midwest
and South.[237]

### Wildlife

Main articles: [Fauna of the United States](/wiki/Fauna_of_the_United_States
"Fauna of the United States") and [Flora of the United
States](/wiki/Flora_of_the_United_States "Flora of the United States")

See also: [Category:Biota of the United
States](/wiki/Category:Biota_of_the_United_States "Category:Biota of the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Bald_Eagle_Portrait.jpg/170px-
Bald_Eagle_Portrait.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bald_Eagle_Portrait.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bald_Eagle_Portrait.jpg "Enlarge")

The [bald eagle](/wiki/Bald_eagle "Bald eagle") has been the [national
bird](/wiki/National_bird_of_the_United_States "National bird of the United
States") of the United States since 1782.[238]

The U.S. ecology is [megadiverse](/wiki/Megadiverse_countries "Megadiverse
countries"): about 17,000 species of [vascular plants](/wiki/Vascular_plant
"Vascular plant") occur in the contiguous United States and Alaska, and over
1,800 species of [flowering plants](/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant")
are found in Hawaii, few of which occur on the mainland.[239] The United
States is home to 428 mammal species, 784 bird species, 311 reptile species,
and 295 amphibian species.[240] About 91,000 insect species have been
described.[241] The [bald eagle](/wiki/Bald_eagle "Bald eagle") is both the
[national bird](/wiki/List_of_national_birds "List of national birds") and
[national animal](/wiki/List_of_national_animals "List of national animals")
of the United States, and is an enduring symbol of the country itself.[242]

There are 59 [national
parks](/wiki/List_of_areas_in_the_United_States_National_Park_System "List of
areas in the United States National Park System") and hundreds of other
federally managed parks, forests, and [wilderness](/wiki/Wilderness
"Wilderness") areas.[243] Altogether, the government owns about 28% of the
country's land area.[244] Most of this is [protected](/wiki/Protected_area
"Protected area"), though some is leased for oil and gas drilling, mining,
logging, or cattle ranching; about .86% is used for military
purposes.[245][246]

[Environmental issues](/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_the_United_States
"Environmental issues in the United States") have been on the national agenda
since 1970. Environmental controversies include debates on oil and [nuclear
energy](/wiki/Nuclear_binding_energy "Nuclear binding energy"), dealing with
air and water pollution, the economic costs of protecting wildlife, logging
and [deforestation](/wiki/Deforestation "Deforestation"),[247][248] and
international responses to global warming.[249][250] Many federal and state
agencies are involved. The most prominent is the [Environmental Protection
Agency](/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency "United States
Environmental Protection Agency") (EPA), created by presidential order in
1970.[251] The idea of wilderness has shaped the management of public lands
since 1964, with the Wilderness Act.[252] The [Endangered Species
Act](/wiki/Endangered_Species_Act "Endangered Species Act") of 1973 is
intended to protect threatened and endangered species and their habitats,
which are monitored by the [United States Fish and Wildlife
Service](/wiki/United_States_Fish_and_Wildlife_Service "United States Fish and
Wildlife Service").[253]

not include [Native Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States
"Native Americans in the United States") until 1860.[256]  
  
The [U.S. Census Bureau](/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States
Census Bureau") estimated the country's population to be 323,425,550 as of
April 25, 2016, and to be adding 1 person (net gain) every 13 seconds, or
about 6,646 people per day.[8] The U.S. population almost quadrupled during
the 20th century, from about 76 million in 1900.[257] The third most populous
nation in the world, after [China](/wiki/China "China") and
[India](/wiki/India "India"), the United States is the only major
industrialized nation in which large population increases are projected.[258]
In the 1800s the average woman had 7.04 children, by the 1900s this number had
decreased to 3.56.[259] Since the early 1970s the birth rate has been below
the replacement rate of 2.1 with 1.86 children per woman in 2014. Foreign born
immigration has caused the US population to continue its rapid increase with
the foreign born population doubling from almost 20 million in 1990 to over 40
million in 2010, representing one third of the population increase.[260] The
foreign born population reached 45 million in 2015.[261][fn 11]

The United States has a birth rate of 13 per 1,000, which is 5 births below
the world average.[265] Its [population growth](/wiki/Population_growth
"Population growth") rate is positive at 0.7%, [higher than that of many
developed
nations](/wiki/Total_fertility_rate#Developed_or_developing_countries "Total
fertility rate").[266] In fiscal year 2015, over one million
[immigrants](/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the United
States") (most of whom entered through [family
reunification](/wiki/Chain_migration#Legislation_and_chain_migration "Chain
migration")) were granted [legal
residence](/wiki/Permanent_residence_\(United_States\) "Permanent residence
\(United States\)").[267] [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") has been the leading
source of new residents since the [1965 Immigration
Act](/wiki/Immigration_and_Nationality_Act_of_1965 "Immigration and
Nationality Act of 1965"). China, India, and the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") have been in the top four
sending countries every year since the 1990s.[268] As of
2012[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit),
approximately 11.4 million residents are [illegal
immigrants](/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States "Illegal
immigration to the United States").[269] As of 2015, 47% of all immigrants are
Hispanic, 26% are Asian, 18% are white and 8% are black. The percentage of
immigrants who are Asian is increasing while the percentage who are Hispanic
is decreasing.[261]

[Minorities](/wiki/Minority_group "Minority group") (as defined by the Census
Bureau as all those beside non-Hispanic, non-multiracial [whites](/wiki/Non-
Hispanic_whites "Non-Hispanic whites")) constituted 37.2% of the population in
2012[270] and over 50% of children under age one,[271][272] and are projected
to constitute the majority by 2044.[271]

According to a survey conducted by the Williams Institute, nine million
Americans, or roughly 3.4% of the adult population identify themselves as
[homosexual](/wiki/Homosexuality "Homosexuality"),
[bisexual](/wiki/Bisexuality "Bisexuality"), or
[transgender](/wiki/Transgender "Transgender").[273][274] A 2016
[Gallup](/wiki/Gallup_\(company\) "Gallup \(company\)") poll also concluded
that 4.1% of adult Americans identified as [LGBT](/wiki/LGBT "LGBT"). The
highest percentage came from the District of Columbia (10%), while the lowest
state was North Dakota at 1.7%.[275] In a 2013 survey, the [Centers for
Disease Control and
Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for
Disease Control and Prevention") found that 96.6% of Americans identify as
straight, while 1.6% identify as gay or lesbian, and 0.7% identify as being
bisexual.[276]

In 2010, the U.S. population included an estimated 5.2 million people with
some [American Indian](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States") or [Alaska Native](/wiki/Alaska_Natives
"Alaska Natives") ancestry (2.9 million exclusively of such ancestry) and 1.2
million with some [native Hawaiian](/wiki/Native_Hawaiians "Native Hawaiians")
or [Pacific island](/wiki/Pacific_Islander "Pacific Islander") ancestry (0.5
million exclusively).[277] The census counted more than 19 million people of
"Some Other Race" who were "unable to identify with any" of its five official
race categories in 2010, over 18.5 million (97%) of whom are of Hispanic
ethnicity.[277]

The population growth of [Hispanic and Latino
Americans](/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans "Hispanic and Latino
Americans") (the terms are officially interchangeable) is a major [demographic
trend](/wiki/Demographic_transition "Demographic transition"). The 50.5
million Americans of Hispanic descent[277] are identified as sharing a
distinct "[ethnicity](/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States_Census
"Race and ethnicity in the United States Census")" by the Census Bureau; 64%
of Hispanic Americans are of [Mexican descent](/wiki/Mexican_American "Mexican
American").[278] Between 2000 and 2010, the country's Hispanic population
increased 43% while the non-Hispanic population rose just 4.9%.[279] Much of
this growth is from immigration; in 2007, 12.6% of the U.S. population was
[foreign-born](/wiki/Foreign_born "Foreign born"), with 54% of that figure
born in [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America").[280][fn 12]

About 82% of Americans live in [urban areas](/wiki/United_States_urban_area
"United States urban area") (including suburbs);[225] about half of those
reside in cities with populations over 50,000.[286] The US has numerous
clusters of cities known as megaregions, the largest being the [Great Lakes
Megalopolis](/wiki/Great_Lakes_Megalopolis "Great Lakes Megalopolis") followed
by the [Northeast Megalopolis](/wiki/Northeast_Megalopolis "Northeast
Megalopolis") and [Southern California](/wiki/Southern_California "Southern
California"). In 2008, 273 [incorporated
municipalities](/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population "List of
United States cities by population") had populations over 100,000, nine cities
had more than one million residents, and four [global
cities](/wiki/Global_city "Global city") had over two million ([New
York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles
"Los Angeles"), [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), and
[Houston](/wiki/Houston "Houston")).[287] There are 52 [metropolitan
areas](/wiki/List_of_Metropolitan_Statistical_Areas "List of Metropolitan
Statistical Areas") with populations greater than one million.[288] Of the 50
fastest-growing metro areas, 47 are in the West or South.[289] The metro areas
of [San Bernardino](/wiki/San_Bernardino,_California "San Bernardino,
California"), [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas "Dallas"), Houston,
[Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"), and [Phoenix](/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona
"Phoenix, Arizona") all grew by more than a million people between 2000 and
2008.[288]

### Language

Main article: [Languages of the United
States](/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_States "Languages of the United States")

See also: [Language Spoken at Home in the United States of
America](/wiki/Language_Spoken_at_Home_in_the_United_States_of_America
"Language Spoken at Home in the United States of America"), [List of
endangered languages in the United
States](/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_the_United_States "List of
endangered languages in the United States"), and [Language education in the
United States](/wiki/Language_education_in_the_United_States "Language
education in the United States")

[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") ([American
English](/wiki/American_English "American English")) is the [de
facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto") [national language](/wiki/National_language
"National language"). Although there is no [official
language](/wiki/Official_language "Official language") at the federal level,
some laws—such as [U.S. naturalization
requirements](/wiki/Naturalized_citizen_of_the_United_States "Naturalized
citizen of the United States")—standardize English. In 2010, about 230
million, or 80% of the population aged five years and older, spoke only
English at home. [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_United_States
"Spanish language in the United States"), spoken by 12% of the population at
home, is the second most common language and the most widely taught second
language.[292][293] Some Americans advocate making English the country's
official language, as it is in 32 states.[294]

Both [Hawaiian](/wiki/Hawaiian_language "Hawaiian language") and English are
official languages in [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"), by state law.[295]
[Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") recognizes [twenty Native
languages](/wiki/Alaska_Native_languages "Alaska Native languages") as well as
English.[296] While neither has an official language, [New
Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico") has laws providing for the use of both
English and Spanish, as [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") does for
English and [French](/wiki/French_language_in_the_United_States "French
language in the United States").[297] Other states, such as
[California](/wiki/California "California"), mandate the publication of
Spanish versions of certain government documents including court forms.[298]

Several insular territories grant official recognition to their native
languages, along with English: [Samoan](/wiki/Samoan_language "Samoan
language")[299] and [Chamorro](/wiki/Chamorro_language "Chamorro
language")[300] are recognized by [American Samoa](/wiki/American_Samoa
"American Samoa") and [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"), respectively;
[Carolinian](/wiki/Carolinian_language "Carolinian language") and Chamorro are
recognized by the [Northern Mariana Islands](/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands
"Northern Mariana Islands");[301] Spanish is an official language of [Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") and is more widely spoken than English
there.[302]

The [most widely taught foreign
languages](/wiki/List_of_most_commonly_learned_foreign_languages_in_the_United_States
"List of most commonly learned foreign languages in the United States") in the
United States, in terms of enrollment numbers from kindergarten through
university undergraduate studies, are: Spanish (around 7.2 million students),
French (1.5 million), and [German](/wiki/German_language_in_the_United_States
"German language in the United States") (500,000). Other commonly taught
languages (with 100,000 to 250,000 learners) include [Latin](/wiki/Latin
"Latin"), [Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_language_education_in_the_United_States
"Japanese language education in the United States"),
[ASL](/wiki/American_Sign_Language "American Sign Language"),
[Italian](/wiki/Italian_language_in_the_United_States "Italian language in the
United States"), and [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language_in_the_United_States
"Chinese language in the United States").[303][304] 18% of all Americans claim
to speak at least one language in addition to English.[305]

### Religion

Main article: [Religion in the United

that began in the United
States](/wiki/List_of_religious_movements_that_began_in_the_United_States
