The [First Amendment](/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"First Amendment to the United States Constitution") of the U.S. Constitution
guarantees the [free exercise](/wiki/Free_Exercise_Clause "Free Exercise
Clause") of religion and forbids Congress from passing laws respecting its
[establishment](/wiki/Establishment_Clause "Establishment Clause").

[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") is by far the most common
religion practiced in the U.S., but other religions are followed, too. In a
2013 survey, 56% of Americans said that religion played a "very important role
in their lives", a far higher figure than that of any other wealthy
nation.[308] In a 2009 Gallup poll, 42% of Americans said that they attended
church weekly or almost weekly; the figures ranged from a low of 23% in
[Vermont](/wiki/Vermont "Vermont") to a high of 63% in Mississippi.[309]
Experts, researchers and authors have referred to the United States as a
"Protestant nation" or "founded on Protestant principles,"[310][311][312][313]
specifically emphasizing its [Calvinist](/wiki/Calvinist "Calvinist")
heritage.[314][315][316]

As with other Western countries, the U.S. is becoming less religious.
[Irreligion](/wiki/Irreligion "Irreligion") is growing rapidly among Americans
under 30.[317] Polls show that overall American confidence in organized
religion has been declining since the mid to late 1980s,[318] and that younger
Americans in particular are becoming increasingly irreligious.[7][319]
According to a 2012 study, the Protestant share of the U.S. population had
dropped to 48%, thus ending its status as religious category of the majority
for the first time.[320][321] Americans with no religion have 1.7 children
compared to 2.2 among Christians. The unaffiliated are less likely to get
married with 37% marrying compared to 52% of Christians.[322]

According to a 2014 survey, 70.6% of adults identified themselves as
[Christian](/wiki/Christianity_in_the_United_States "Christianity in the
United States"),[323] [Protestant](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism")
denominations accounted for 46.5%, while [Roman
Catholicism](/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_United_States "Catholic Church in
the United States"), at 20.8%, was the largest individual denomination.[324]
The total reporting non-Christian religions in 2014 was 5.9%.[324] Other
religions include [Judaism](/wiki/American_Jews "American Jews") (1.9%),
[Islam](/wiki/Islam_in_the_United_States "Islam in the United States") (0.9%),
[Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_United_States "Buddhism in the United
States") (0.7%), [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_States "Hinduism in
the United States") (0.7%).[324] The survey also reported that 22.8% of
Americans described themselves as [agnostic](/wiki/Agnosticism "Agnosticism"),
[atheist](/wiki/Atheism "Atheism") or simply having [no
religion](/wiki/Irreligion "Irreligion"), up from 8.2% in 1990.[324][325][326]
There are also [Unitarian Universalist](/wiki/Unitarian_Universalist
"Unitarian Universalist"), [Baha'i](/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith "Bahá'í
Faith"), [Sikh](/wiki/Sikh "Sikh"), [Jain](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism"),
[Shinto](/wiki/Shinto "Shinto"), [Confucian](/wiki/Confucianism
"Confucianism"), [Taoist](/wiki/Taoism "Taoism"), [Druid](/wiki/Neo-Druidism
"Neo-Druidism"), [Native American](/wiki/Native_American_religion "Native
American religion"), [Wiccan](/wiki/Wicca "Wicca"),
[humanist](/wiki/Religious_humanism "Religious humanism") and
[deist](/wiki/Deism "Deism") communities.[327]

[Protestantism](/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_United_States "Protestantism in the
United States") is the largest Christian religious grouping in the United
States. Baptists collectively form the largest branch of Protestantism, and
the [Southern Baptist Convention](/wiki/Southern_Baptist_Convention "Southern
Baptist Convention") is the largest individual Protestant denomination. [Roman
Catholicism](/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_United_States "Catholic Church in
the United States") in the United States has its origin primarily in the
[Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas "Spanish colonization of
the Americas") and [French](/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas "French
colonization of the Americas") colonization of the Americas and, in part, in
the English Catholic Proprietary of Maryland,[328] It later grew because of
Irish, Italian, Polish, German and Hispanic immigration. Rhode Island has the
highest percentage of Catholics with 40 percent of the total population.[329]
[Lutheranism](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism") in the U.S. has its origin in
immigration from [Northern Europe](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe")
and [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"). [North](/wiki/North_Dakota "North
Dakota") and [South Dakota](/wiki/South_Dakota "South Dakota") are the only
states in which a plurality of the population is Lutheran.
[Presbyterianism](/wiki/Presbyterianism "Presbyterianism") was introduced in
North America by [Scottish](/wiki/Scottish_people "Scottish people") and
[Ulster Scots](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_people "Ulster Scots people") immigrants.
Although it has spread across the United States, it is heavily concentrated on
the East Coast. [Dutch Reformed](/wiki/Dutch_Reformed "Dutch Reformed")
congregations were founded first in [New Amsterdam](/wiki/New_Amsterdam "New
Amsterdam") (New York City) before spreading westward. [Utah](/wiki/Utah
"Utah") is the only state where [Mormonism](/wiki/Mormonism "Mormonism") is
the religion of the majority of the population. The [Mormon
Corridor](/wiki/Mormon_Corridor "Mormon Corridor") also extends to parts of
[Idaho](/wiki/Idaho "Idaho"), [Nevada](/wiki/Nevada "Nevada") and
[Wyoming](/wiki/Wyoming "Wyoming").[330]

The [Bible Belt](/wiki/Bible_Belt "Bible Belt") is an informal term for a
region in the [Southern United States](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern
United States") in which socially conservative Evangelical Protestantism is a
significant part of the culture and Christian church attendance across the
denominations is generally higher than the nation's average. By contrast,
religion plays the least important role in [New England](/wiki/New_England
"New England") and in the [Western United States](/wiki/Western_United_States
"Western United States").[309]

### Family structure

Main article: [Family structure in the United
States](/wiki/Family_structure_in_the_United_States "Family structure in the
United States")

As of
2007[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit),
58% of Americans age 18 and over were married, 6% were widowed, 10% were
divorced, and 25% had never been married.[331] Women now work mostly outside
the home and receive a majority of [bachelor's
degrees](/wiki/Educational_attainment_in_the_United_States "Educational
attainment in the United States").[332]

The U.S. [teenage pregnancy](/wiki/Teenage_pregnancy "Teenage pregnancy") rate
is 26.5 per 1,000 women. The rate has declined by 57% since 1991.[333] In
2013, the highest teenage birth rate was in [Alabama](/wiki/Alabama
"Alabama"), and the lowest in [Wyoming](/wiki/Wyoming "Wyoming").[333][334]
[Abortion](/wiki/Abortion_in_the_United_States "Abortion in the United
States") is legal throughout the U.S., owing to _[Roe v.
Wade](/wiki/Roe_v._Wade "Roe v. Wade")_ , a 1973 [landmark
decision](/wiki/Lists_of_landmark_court_decisions "Lists of landmark court
decisions") by the [Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States"). While the abortion rate is falling, the abortion ratio of 241 per
1,000 live births and abortion rate of 15 per 1,000 women aged 15–44 remain
higher than those of most Western nations.[335] In 2013, the average age at
first birth was 26 and 40.6% of births were to unmarried women.[336]

The [total fertility rate](/wiki/Total_fertility_rate "Total fertility rate")
(TFR) was estimated for 2013 at 1.86 births per woman.[337] [Adoption in the
United States](/wiki/Adoption_in_the_United_States "Adoption in the United
States") is common and relatively easy from a legal point of view (compared to
other Western countries).[338] In 2001, with over 127,000 adoptions, the U.S.
accounted for nearly half of the total number of adoptions worldwide.[339]
[Same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_United_States "Same-sex
marriage in the United States") is legal nationwide and it is legal for same-
sex [couples to adopt.](/wiki/LGBT_adoption_in_the_United_States "LGBT
adoption in the United States") [Polygamy](/wiki/Polygamy "Polygamy") is
illegal throughout the U.S.[340]

United States"), and [Elections in the United
States](/wiki/Elections_in_the_United_States "Elections in the United States")

[Supreme Court Building](/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United

States") sits

The United States is the world's oldest surviving
[federation](/wiki/Federation "Federation"). It is a [representative
democracy](/wiki/Representative_democracy "Representative democracy"), "in
which [majority rule](/wiki/Majority_rule "Majority rule") is tempered by
[minority rights](/wiki/Minority_rights "Minority rights") protected by
[law](/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States "Law of the United States")".[341] The
government is regulated by a system of [checks and
balances](/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers") defined by the
U.S. Constitution, which serves as the country's supreme legal document.[342]
For 2016, the U.S. ranked 21st on the [Democracy Index](/wiki/Democracy_Index
"Democracy Index")[343] (tied with [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy")) and 18th on
the [Corruption Perceptions Index](/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index
"Corruption Perceptions Index").[344]

In the [American federalist system](/wiki/Federalism#United_States
"Federalism"), citizens are usually subject to [three levels of
government](/wiki/Political_divisions_of_the_United_States "Political
divisions of the United States"): federal, state, and local. The [local
government](/wiki/Local_government_in_the_United_States "Local government in
the United States")'s duties are commonly split between
[county](/wiki/County_\(United_States\) "County \(United States\)") and
[municipal governments](/wiki/Municipal_corporation "Municipal corporation").
In almost all cases, executive and legislative officials are elected by a
[plurality vote](/wiki/Plurality_voting_system "Plurality voting system") of
citizens by district. There is no [proportional
representation](/wiki/Proportional_representation "Proportional
representation") at the federal level, and it is rare at lower levels.[345]

The federal government is composed of three branches:

  * [Legislative](/wiki/Legislature "Legislature"): The [bicameral](/wiki/Bicameralism "Bicameralism") [Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"), made up of the [Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") and the [House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives"), makes [federal law](/wiki/Federal_law "Federal law"), [declares war](/wiki/Declaration_of_war "Declaration of war"), approves treaties, has the [power of the purse](/wiki/Power_of_the_purse "Power of the purse"),[346] and has the power of [impeachment](/wiki/Impeachment "Impeachment"), by which it can remove sitting members of the government.[347]
  * [Executive](/wiki/Executive_\(government\) "Executive \(government\)"): [The President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") is the [commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-chief "Commander-in-chief") of the military, can veto [legislative bills](/wiki/Bill_\(law\) "Bill \(law\)") before they become law (subject to Congressional override), and appoints the [members of the Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States") (subject to Senate approval) and other officers, who administer and enforce federal laws and policies.[348]
  * [Judicial](/wiki/Judiciary "Judiciary"): The [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States") and lower [federal courts](/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States "Federal judiciary of the United States"), whose judges are appointed by the President with Senate approval, interpret laws and overturn those they find [unconstitutional](/wiki/Constitutionality "Constitutionality").[349]

The House of Representatives has 435 voting members, each representing a
[congressional district](/wiki/Congressional_district "Congressional
district") for a two-year term. House seats are
[apportioned](/wiki/United_States_congressional_apportionment "United States
congressional apportionment") among the states by population every tenth year.
At the [2010 census](/wiki/2000_United_States_Census "2000 United States
Census"), seven states had the minimum of one representative, while
California, the most populous state, had 53.[350]

The Senate has 100 members with each state having two senators, elected [at-
large](/wiki/At-large "At-large") to six-year terms; one third of Senate seats
are up for election every other year. The President serves a four-year term
and may be elected to the office [no more than
twice](/wiki/Term_limits_in_the_United_States "Term limits in the United
States"). The President is [not elected by direct
vote](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election "United States presidential
election"), but by an indirect [electoral
college](/wiki/Electoral_College_\(United_States\) "Electoral College \(United
States\)") system in which the determining votes are apportioned to the states
and the [District of Columbia](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington,
D.C.").[351] The Supreme Court, led by the [Chief Justice of the United
States](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief Justice of the United
States"), has nine members, who serve for life.[352]

The state governments are structured in roughly similar fashion;
[Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska") uniquely has a
[unicameral](/wiki/Unicameralism "Unicameralism") legislature.[353] The
[governor](/wiki/Governor_\(United_States\) "Governor \(United States\)")
(chief executive) of each state is directly elected. Some state judges and
cabinet officers are appointed by the governors of the respective states,
while others are elected by popular vote.

The original text of the Constitution establishes the structure and
responsibilities of the federal government and its relationship with the
individual states. [Article
One](/wiki/Article_One_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article One of the
United States Constitution") protects the right to the "great writ" of [habeas
corpus](/wiki/Habeas_corpus_in_the_United_States "Habeas corpus in the United
States"). The Constitution has been amended 27 times;[354] the first ten
amendments, which make up the [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights"),
and the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") form the central
basis of Americans' individual rights. All laws and governmental procedures
are subject to [judicial review](/wiki/Judicial_review "Judicial review") and
any law ruled by the courts to be in violation of the Constitution is voided.
The principle of judicial review, not explicitly mentioned in the
Constitution, was established by the Supreme Court in _[Marbury v.
Madison](/wiki/Marbury_v._Madison "Marbury v. Madison")_ (1803)[355] in a
decision handed down by [Chief Justice John Marshall](/wiki/John_Marshall
"John Marshall").[356]

### Political divisions

Main articles: [Political divisions of the United
States](/wiki/Political_divisions_of_the_United_States "Political divisions of
the United States"), [U.S. state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state"), [Territories
of the United States](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of
the United States"), [List of states and territories of the United
States](/wiki/List_of_states_and_territories_of_the_United_States "List of
states and territories of the United States"), and [Indian
reservation](/wiki/Indian_reservation "Indian reservation")

Further information: [Territorial evolution of the United
States](/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_the_United_States "Territorial
evolution of the United States") and [United States territorial
acquisitions](/wiki/United_States_territorial_acquisitions "United States
territorial acquisitions")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/US.EEZ_Pacific_centered_NOAA_map.png/220px-
US.EEZ_Pacific_centered_NOAA_map.png)](/wiki/File:US.EEZ_Pacific_centered_NOAA_map.png)

[](/wiki/File:US.EEZ_Pacific_centered_NOAA_map.png "Enlarge")

Map of U.S. [Economic Exclusion Zone](/wiki/Economic_Exclusion_Zone "Economic
Exclusion Zone"),[357] highlighting states, territories and possessions

The United States is a federal republic of 50 states, a federal district, five
territories and eleven uninhabited island possessions.[358] The states and
territories are the principal administrative districts in the country. These
are divided into subdivisions of counties and independent cities. The District
of Columbia is a federal district that contains the capital of the United
States, Washington DC.[359] The states and the District of Columbia choose the
President of the United States. Each state has presidential electors equal to
the number of their Representatives and Senators in Congress; the District of
Columbia has three.[360]

Congressional Districts are reapportioned among the states following each
decennial Census of Population. Each state then draws single member districts
to conform with the census apportionment. The total number of Representatives
is 435, and delegate Members of Congress represent the District of Columbia
and the five major U.S. territories.[361]

The United States also observes [tribal
sovereignty](/wiki/Tribal_sovereignty_in_the_United_States "Tribal sovereignty
in the United States") of the American Indian nations to a limited degree, as
it does with the states' sovereignty. American Indians are U.S. citizens and
tribal lands are subject to the jurisdiction of the U.S. Congress and the
federal courts. Like the states they have a great deal of autonomy, but also
like the states, tribes are not allowed to make war, engage in their own
foreign relations, or print and issue currency.[362]

### Parties and elections

Main articles: [Politics of the United
States](/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_States "Politics of the United States")
and [Political ideologies in the United
States](/wiki/Political_ideologies_in_the_United_States "Political ideologies
in the United States")

The United States has operated under a [two-party system](/wiki/Two-
party_system "Two-party system") for most of its history.[364] For elective
offices at most levels, state-administered [primary
elections](/wiki/Primary_election "Primary election") choose the major party
[nominees](/wiki/Nomination "Nomination") for subsequent [general
elections](/wiki/General_election "General election"). Since the [general
election of 1856](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1856 "United
States presidential election, 1856"), the major parties have been the
[Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)"), [founded in
1824](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_Democratic_Party "History of the
United States Democratic Party"), and the [Republican
Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)"), [founded in
1854](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_Republican_Party "History of the
United States Republican Party"). Since the Civil War, only one [third-
party](/wiki/Third_party_\(United_States\) "Third party \(United States\)")
presidential candidate—former president [Theodore
Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt"), running as a
[Progressive](/wiki/Progressive_Party_\(United_States,_1912\) "Progressive
Party \(United States, 1912\)") in
[1912](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1912 "United States
presidential election, 1912")—has won as much as 20% of the popular vote. The
President and Vice-president are elected through the [Electoral
College](/wiki/Electoral_College_\(United_States\) "Electoral College \(United
States\)") system.[365]

Within American [political culture](/wiki/Political_culture "Political
culture"), the [center-right](/wiki/Center-right_politics "Center-right
politics") Republican Party is considered
"[conservative](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the
United States")" and the [center-left](/wiki/Centre-left_politics "Centre-left
politics") Democratic Party is considered
"[liberal](/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States "Modern liberalism in
the United States")".[366][367] The states of the
[Northeast](/wiki/Politics_of_the_Northeastern_United_States "Politics of the
Northeastern United States") and [West
Coast](/wiki/Politics_of_the_Western_United_States "Politics of the Western
United States") and some of the Great Lakes states, known as "[blue
states](/wiki/Red_states_and_blue_states "Red states and blue states")", are
relatively liberal. The "[red
states](/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_U.S._states "Political party
strength in U.S. states")" of the
[South](/wiki/Politics_of_the_Southern_United_States "Politics of the Southern
United States") and parts of the [Great
Plains](/wiki/Midwestern_United_States#Political_trends "Midwestern United
States") and [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Politics_of_the_Western_United_States
"Politics of the Western United States") are relatively conservative.

[Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)") [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump"), the
winner of the [2016 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_Presidential_Election,_2016 "United States
Presidential Election, 2016"), is currently serving as the 45th [President of
the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the
United States").[368] Current leadership in the Senate includes Republican
Vice President [Mike Pence](/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike Pence"), Republican
President Pro Tempore [Orrin Hatch](/wiki/Orrin_Hatch "Orrin Hatch"),
[Majority Leader](/wiki/Party_leaders_of_the_United_States_Senate "Party
leaders of the United States Senate") [Mitch McConnell](/wiki/Mitch_McConnell
"Mitch McConnell"), and Minority Leader [Chuck Schumer](/wiki/Chuck_Schumer
"Chuck Schumer").[369] Leadership in the House includes Speaker of the House
[Paul Ryan](/wiki/Paul_Ryan "Paul Ryan"), [Majority
Leader](/wiki/Party_leaders_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives
"Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives") [Kevin
McCarthy](/wiki/Kevin_McCarthy_\(California_politician\) "Kevin McCarthy
\(California politician\)"), and Minority Leader [Nancy
Pelosi](/wiki/Nancy_Pelosi "Nancy Pelosi").[370]

In the [115th United States Congress](/wiki/115th_United_States_Congress
"115th United States Congress"), both the [House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives") and the [Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United
States Senate") are controlled by the Republican Party. The Senate currently
consists of 52 Republicans, and 46 Democrats with 2
[Independents](/wiki/Independent_politician "Independent politician") who
caucus with the Democrats; the House consists of 241 Republicans and 194
Democrats.[371] In state governorships, there are 33 Republicans, 16
Democrats, and 1 Independent.[372] Among the DC mayor and the 5 territorial
governors, there are 2 Republicans, 1 Democrat, 1 [New
Progressive](/wiki/New_Progressive_Party_of_Puerto_Rico "New Progressive Party
of Puerto Rico"), and 2 Independents.[373]

### Foreign relations

Main articles: [Foreign relations of the United
States](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_States "Foreign relations of the
United States") and [Foreign policy of the United
States](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States "Foreign policy of the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/67%C2%BA_Per%C3%ADodo_de_Sesiones_de_la_Asamblea_General_de_Naciones_Unidas_%288020913157%29.jpg/220px-67%C2%BA_Per%C3%ADodo_de_Sesiones_de_la_Asamblea_General_de_Naciones_Unidas_%288020913157%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:67%C2%BA_Per%C3%ADodo_de_Sesiones_de_la_Asamblea_General_de_Naciones_Unidas_\(8020913157\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:67%C2%BA_Per%C3%ADodo_de_Sesiones_de_la_Asamblea_General_de_Naciones_Unidas_\(8020913157\).jpg
"Enlarge")

The [United Nations Headquarters](/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations
"Headquarters of the United Nations") was built in [Midtown
Manhattan](/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan "Midtown Manhattan") in 1952.[374]

The United States has an established structure of foreign relations. It is a
permanent member of the [United Nations Security
Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security
Council"), and New York City is home to the [United Nations
Headquarters](/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the
United Nations"). It is a member of the [G7](/wiki/G7 "G7"),[375]
[G20](/wiki/G20 "G20"), and [Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development](/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development
"Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development"). Almost all
countries have
[embassies](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_the_United_States "List of
diplomatic missions in the United States") in Washington, D.C., and many have
[consulates](/wiki/Consul_\(representative\) "Consul \(representative\)")
around the country. Likewise, nearly all nations host [American diplomatic
missions](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_United_States "List of
diplomatic missions of the United States"). However,
[Iran](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Iran–United States
relations"), [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations
"North Korea–United States relations"),
[Bhutan](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bhutan "Foreign relations of Bhutan"), and
the [Republic of China](/wiki/Taiwan%E2%80%93United_States_relations
"Taiwan–United States relations") (Taiwan) do not have formal diplomatic
relations with the United States (although the U.S. still maintains relations
with Taiwan and supplies it with [military equipment](/wiki/Six_Assurances
"Six Assurances")).[376]

The United States has a "[Special Relationship](/wiki/Special_Relationship
"Special Relationship")" with the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom%E2%80%93United_States_relations "United
Kingdom–United States relations")[377] and strong ties with
[Canada](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Canada–United States
relations"),[378] [Australia](/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93United_States_relations
"Australia–United States relations"),[379] [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand%E2%80%93United_States_relations "New Zealand–United
States relations"),[380] [the
Philippines](/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_relations
"Philippines–United States relations"),[381]
[Japan](/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Japan–United States
relations"),[382] [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "South Korea–United
States relations"),[383] [Israel](/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations
"Israel–United States relations"),[384] and several [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") countries, including
[France](/wiki/France%E2%80%93United_States_relations "France–United States
relations"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Italy–United
States relations"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93United_States_relations
"Germany–United States relations"), and
[Spain](/wiki/Spain%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Spain–United States
relations"). It works closely with fellow [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") members on
military and security issues and with its neighbors through the [Organization
of American States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of
American States") and [free trade
agreements](/wiki/United_States_free_trade_agreements "United States free
trade agreements") such as the trilateral [North American Free Trade
Agreement](/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement "North American Free
Trade Agreement") with Canada and
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Mexico–United States
relations"). In 2008, the United States spent a net $25.4 billion on [official
development assistance](/wiki/Official_development_assistance "Official
development assistance"), the most in the world. As a share of America's large
[gross national income](/wiki/Gross_national_income "Gross national income")
(GNI), however, the U.S. contribution of 0.18% ranked last among 22 donor
states. By contrast, private overseas giving by Americans is relatively
generous.[385]

The U.S. exercises full international defense authority and responsibility for
three sovereign nations through [Compact of Free
Association](/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association "Compact of Free Association")
with [Micronesia](/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia "Federated States of
Micronesia"), the [Marshall Islands](/wiki/Marshall_Islands "Marshall
Islands") and [Palau](/wiki/Palau "Palau"). These are Pacific island nations,
once part of the U.S.-administered [Trust Territory of the Pacific
Islands](/wiki/Trust_Territory_of_the_Pacific_Islands "Trust Territory of the
Pacific Islands") after World War II, which gained independence in subsequent
years.[386]

On October 25, 2017, Vice President Mike Pence announced at a _In Defense of
Christians_ annual dinner meeting in Washington that the United States would
stop funding United Nations relief efforts, cases tackling the persecution of
Christians in the Middle East, but insisted that the U.S. would instead help
and aid Christians directly through the [U.S. Agency for International
Development](/wiki/U.S._Agency_for_International_Development "U.S. Agency for
International Development").[387] Pence said that he will be visiting the
Middle East in December and will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin
Netanyahu and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas to discuss peace
agreements.[388][389]

### Government finance

See also: [Taxation in the United States](/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States
"Taxation in the United States") and [United States federal
budget](/wiki/United_States_federal_budget "United States federal budget")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png/425px-
Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png)](/wiki/File:Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png)

[](/wiki/File:Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png "Enlarge")

US federal debt held by the public as a percentage of GDP, from 1790 to
2013.[390]

[Taxes in the United States](/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States "Taxation in
the United States") are levied at the federal, state, and local government
levels. These include taxes on income, payroll, property, sales, imports,
estates and gifts, as well as various fees. In 2010 taxes collected by
federal, state and municipal governments amounted to 24.8% of
[GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product").[391] During
FY2012, the federal government collected approximately $2.45 trillion in tax
revenue, up $147 billion or 6% versus FY2011 revenues of $2.30 trillion.
Primary receipt categories included individual income taxes ($1,132B or 47%),
Social Security/Social Insurance taxes ($845B or 35%), and corporate taxes
($242B or 10%).[392] Based on CBO estimates,[393] under 2013 tax law the top
1% will be paying the highest average tax rates since 1979, while other income
groups will remain at historic lows.[394]

U.S. taxation is generally [progressive](/wiki/Progressive_tax "Progressive
tax"), especially the federal income taxes, and is among the most progressive
in the developed world.[395][396][397][398][399] The highest 10% of income
earners pay a majority of federal taxes,[400] and about half of all
taxes.[401] Payroll taxes for Social Security are a flat [regressive
tax](/wiki/Regressive_tax "Regressive tax"), with no tax charged on income
above $118,500 (for 2015 and 2016) and no tax at all paid on [unearned
income](/wiki/Unearned_income "Unearned income") from things such as stocks
and capital gains.[402][403] The historic reasoning for the regressive nature
of the payroll tax is that entitlement programs have not been viewed as
welfare transfers.[404][405] However, according to the [Congressional Budget
Office](/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office "Congressional Budget Office") the
net effect of Social Security is that the benefit to tax ratio ranges from
roughly 70% for the top earnings quintile to about 170% for the lowest earning
quintile, making the system progressive.[406]

The top 10% paid 51.8% of total federal taxes in 2009, and the top 1%, with
13.4% of pre-tax national income, paid 22.3% of federal taxes.[407] In 2013
the Tax Policy Center projected total federal effective tax rates of 35.5% for
the top 1%, 27.2% for the top quintile, 13.8% for the middle quintile, and
−2.7% for the bottom quintile.[408][409] The [incidence](/wiki/Tax_incidence
"Tax incidence") of [corporate income
tax](/wiki/Corporate_tax_in_the_United_States "Corporate tax in the United
States") has been a matter of considerable ongoing controversy for
decades.[398][410] State and local taxes vary widely, but are generally less
progressive than federal taxes as they rely heavily on broadly borne
[regressive](/wiki/Regressive_tax "Regressive tax") sales and property taxes
that yield less volatile revenue streams, though their consideration does not
eliminate the progressive nature of overall taxation.[398][411]

During FY 2012, the federal government spent $3.54 trillion on a budget or
cash basis, down $60 billion or 1.7% vs. FY 2011 spending of $3.60 trillion.
Major categories of FY 2012 spending included: Medicare & Medicaid ($802B or
23% of spending), Social Security ($768B or 22%), Defense Department ($670B or
19%), non-defense discretionary ($615B or 17%), other mandatory ($461B or 13%)
and interest ($223B or 6%).[392]

The total [national debt of the United
States](/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States "National debt of the United
States") in the United States was $18.527 trillion (106% of the GDP) in
2014.[412][fn 14]

### Military

Main article: [United States Armed Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces
"United States Armed Forces")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force%2C_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk%2C_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg/220px-
thumbnail.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force,_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk,_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force,_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk,_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [carrier strike groups](/wiki/Carrier_strike_group "Carrier strike group")
of the _[Kitty Hawk](/wiki/USS_Kitty_Hawk_\(CV-63\) "USS Kitty Hawk
\(CV-63\)")_ , _[Ronald Reagan](/wiki/USS_Ronald_Reagan_\(CVN-76\) "USS Ronald
Reagan \(CVN-76\)")_ , and _[Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/USS_Abraham_Lincoln_\(CVN-72\) "USS Abraham Lincoln
\(CVN-72\)")_ with aircraft from the [Marine
Corps](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps"),
[Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy"), and [Air
Force](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force").

The President holds the title of [commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-chief
"Commander-in-chief") of the nation's armed forces and appoints its leaders,
the [Secretary of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense "United
States Secretary of Defense") and the [Joint Chiefs of
Staff](/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Joint Chiefs of Staff"). The [United
States Department of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense
"United States Department of Defense") administers the armed forces, including
the [Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army"), [Marine
Corps](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps"),
[Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy"), and [Air
Force](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force"). The [Coast
Guard](/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast Guard") is run by
the [Department of Homeland
Security](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security "United States
Department of Homeland Security") in peacetime and by the [Department of the
Navy](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Navy "United States Department of
the Navy") during times of war. In 2008, the armed forces had 1.4 million
personnel on active duty. The
[Reserves](/wiki/Reserve_components_of_the_United_States_Armed_Forces "Reserve
components of the United States Armed Forces") and [National
Guard](/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States "National Guard of the United
States") brought the total number of troops to 2.3 million. The Department of
Defense also employed about 700,000 civilians, not including contractors.[417]

Military service is voluntary, though
[conscription](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the
United States") may occur in wartime through the [Selective Service
System](/wiki/Selective_Service_System "Selective Service System").[418]
American forces can be rapidly deployed by the Air Force's large fleet of
transport aircraft, the Navy's 11 active [aircraft
carriers](/wiki/Aircraft_carrier "Aircraft carrier"), and [Marine
expeditionary units](/wiki/Marine_expeditionary_unit "Marine expeditionary
unit") at sea with the Navy's [Atlantic
and](/wiki/United_States_Fleet_Forces_Command "United States Fleet Forces
Command") [Pacific fleets](/wiki/United_States_Pacific_Fleet "United States
Pacific Fleet"). The military operates 865 bases and facilities abroad,[419]
and maintains [deployments greater than 100 active duty
personnel](/wiki/United_States_military_deployments "United States military
deployments") in 25 foreign countries.[420]

The [military budget of the United
States](/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States "Military budget of the
United States") in 2011 was more than $700 billion, 41% of global military
spending and equal to the next 14 largest national military expenditures
combined. At 4.7% of GDP, the rate was the second-highest among the top 15
military spenders, after [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi
Arabia").[421] U.S. defense spending as a percentage of GDP ranked 23rd
globally in 2012 according to the CIA.[422] Defense's share of U.S. spending
has generally declined in recent decades, from Cold War peaks of 14.2% of GDP
in 1953 and 69.5% of federal outlays in 1954 to 4.7% of GDP and 18.8% of
federal outlays in 2011.[423]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/US_Global_Military_Presence.svg/220px-
US_Global_Military_Presence.svg.png)](/wiki/File:US_Global_Military_Presence.svg)

[](/wiki/File:US_Global_Military_Presence.svg "Enlarge")

US global military presence.

The proposed base [Department of Defense
budget](/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States "Military budget of the
United States") for 2012, $553 billion, was a 4.2% increase over 2011; an
additional $118 billion was proposed for the military campaigns in Iraq and
Afghanistan.[424] The last American troops serving in Iraq departed in
December 2011;[425] 4,484 service members were killed during the [Iraq
War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War").[426] Approximately 90,000 U.S. troops were
serving in Afghanistan in April 2012;[427] by November 8, 2013 2,285 had been
killed during the [War in
Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%932014\) "War in
Afghanistan \(2001–2014\)").[428]

## Law enforcement and crime

Main articles: [Law enforcement in the United
States](/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Law enforcement in the
United States") and [Crime in the United
States](/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States "Crime in the United States")

See also: [Law of the United States](/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States "Law of
the United States"), [Second Amendment to the United States
Constitution](/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Second
Amendment to the United States Constitution"), [Human rights in the United
States § Justice
system](/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_United_States#Justice_system "Human rights
in the United States"), [Incarceration in the United
States](/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States "Incarceration in the United
States"), and [Capital punishment in the United
States](/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States "Capital punishment in
the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg/220px-
Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg "Enlarge")

Law enforcement in the U.S. is maintained primarily by local police
departments.[429]

Law enforcement in the United States is primarily the responsibility of local
police and [sheriff](/wiki/Sheriff "Sheriff")'s departments, with [state
police](/wiki/State_police "State police") providing broader services. The
[New York City Police Department](/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department "New
York City Police Department") (NYPD) is the largest in the country. Federal
agencies such as the [Federal Bureau of
Investigation](/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of
Investigation") (FBI) and the [U.S. Marshals
Service](/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service "United States Marshals
Service") have specialized duties, including protecting [civil
rights](/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights"), [national
security](/wiki/National_Security_of_the_United_States "National Security of
the United States") and enforcing [U.S. federal
courts](/wiki/U.S._federal_courts "U.S. federal courts")' rulings and federal
laws.[430] At the federal level and in almost every state, a legal system
operates on a [common law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law"). State courts
conduct most criminal trials; [federal
courts](/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States "Federal judiciary of the
United States") handle certain designated crimes as well as certain appeals
from the state criminal courts. [Plea bargaining in the United
States](/wiki/Plea_bargaining_in_the_United_States "Plea bargaining in the
United States") is very common; the vast majority of criminal cases in the
country are settled by [plea bargain](/wiki/Plea_bargain "Plea bargain")
rather than [jury trial](/wiki/Jury_trial "Jury trial").[431]

In 2015, there were 15,696 murders which was 1,532 more than in 2014, a 10.8
per cent increase, the largest since 1971.[432] The murder rate in 2015 was
4.9 per 100,000 people.[433] In 2016 the murder rate increased by 8.6%, with
17,250 murders that year.[434] The national [clearance
rate](/wiki/Clearance_rate "Clearance rate") for homicides in 2015 was 64.1%,
compared to 90% in 1965.[435] In 2012 there were 4.7 murders per 100,000
persons in the United States, a 54% decline from the modern peak of 10.2 in
1980.[436] In 2001–2, the United States had above-average levels of violent
crime and particularly high levels of [gun
violence](/wiki/Gun_violence_in_the_United_States "Gun violence in the United
States") compared to other developed nations.[437] A cross-sectional analysis
of the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World
Health Organization") Mortality Database from 2010 showed that United States
"homicide rates were 7.0 times higher than in other high-income countries,
driven by a gun homicide rate that was 25.2 times higher."[438] [Gun ownership
rights](/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Second
Amendment to the United States Constitution") continue to be the subject of
[contentious political debate](/wiki/Gun_politics_in_the_United_States "Gun
politics in the United States").

From 1980 through 2008 males represented 77% of homicide victims and 90% of
offenders. Blacks committed 52.5% of all homicides during that span, at a rate
almost eight times that of whites ("whites" includes most Hispanics), and were
victimized at a rate six times that of whites. Most homicides were
intraracial, with 93% of black victims killed by blacks and 84% of white
victims killed by whites.[439] In 2012, Louisiana had the highest rate of
murder and non-negligent manslaughter in the U.S., and New Hampshire the
lowest.[440] The FBI's [Uniform Crime Reports](/wiki/Uniform_Crime_Reports
"Uniform Crime Reports") estimates that there were 3,246 violent and property
crimes per 100,000 residents in 2012, for a total of over 9 million total
crimes.[441]

[Capital punishment](/wiki/Capital_punishment "Capital punishment") is
sanctioned in the United States for certain federal and military crimes, and
used in 31 states.[442][443] No executions took place from 1967 to 1977, owing
in part to a [U.S. Supreme Court ruling](/wiki/Furman_v._Georgia "Furman v.
Georgia") striking down arbitrary imposition of the death penalty. In 1976,
that Court ruled that, under appropriate circumstances, capital punishment may
constitutionally be imposed. Since the decision there have been more than
1,300 executions, a majority of these taking place in three states: Texas,
Virginia, and [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma").[444] Meanwhile, [several
states](/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States#States_without_capital_punishment
"Capital punishment in the United States") have either abolished or struck
down death penalty laws. In 2015, the country had the fifth-highest number of
executions in the world, following China, [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran"),
[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") and [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia
"Saudi Arabia").[445]

The United States has the [highest documented incarceration
rate](/wiki/United_States_incarceration_rate "United States incarceration
rate") and [total prison population](/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States
"Incarceration in the United States") in the world.[446] At the start of 2008,
more than 2.3 million people were incarcerated, more than one in every 100
adults.[447] In December 2012, the combined U.S. adult correctional systems
supervised about 6,937,600 offenders. About 1 in every 35 adult residents in
the United States was under some form of correctional supervision in December
2012, the lowest rate observed since 1997.[448] The prison population has
quadrupled since 1980,[449] and state and local spending on prisons and jails
has grown three times as much as that spent on public education during the
same period.[450] However, the imprisonment rate for all prisoners sentenced
to more than a year in state or federal facilities is 478 per 100,000 in
2013[451] and the rate for pre-trial/remand prisoners is 153 per 100,000
residents in 2012.[452] The country's high rate of incarceration is largely
due to changes in [sentencing
guidelines](/wiki/United_States_Federal_Sentencing_Guidelines "United States
Federal Sentencing Guidelines") and [drug
policies](/wiki/Federal_drug_policy_of_the_United_States "Federal drug policy
of the United States").[453] According to the [Federal Bureau of
Prisons](/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Prisons "Federal Bureau of Prisons"), the
majority of inmates held in federal prisons are convicted of drug
offenses.[454] The [privatization of
prisons](/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States#Privatization "Incarceration
in the United States") and prison services which began in the 1980s has been a
subject of debate.[455][456] In 2008, Louisiana [had the highest incarceration
rate](/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_incarceration_rate#Incarceration_rate_by_state
"List of U.S. states by incarceration rate"),[457] and Maine the lowest.[458]

## Economy

Main article: [Economy of the United
States](/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States "Economy of the United States")

See also: [Economic history of the United
States](/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_United_States "Economic history of the
United States")

Economic indicators

Real GDP growth | 1.4% (Q2 2016) | [459]  
| 2.6% (2015) | [460]

[Employment-to-population ratio](/wiki/Employment-to-population_ratio "Employment-to-population ratio") | 59.7% (August 2016) | [462]

[Labor force](/wiki/Labor_force#Labor_force_in_the_United_States "Labor force") participation rate | 62.8% (August 2016) | [464]
