[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png/315px-
United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png)](/wiki/File:United_States_Export_Treemap_\(2011\).png)

[](/wiki/File:United_States_Export_Treemap_\(2011\).png "Enlarge")

United States export treemap (2011): The U.S. is the world's second-largest
exporter.

The United States has a [capitalist](/wiki/Capitalism "Capitalism") [mixed
economy](/wiki/Mixed_economy "Mixed economy")[467] which is fueled by abundant
[natural resources](/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural resource") and high
productivity.[468] According to the [International Monetary
Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund"), the
U.S. GDP of $16.8 trillion constitutes 24% of the [gross world
product](/wiki/Gross_world_product "Gross world product") at market exchange
rates and over 19% of the gross world product at [purchasing power
parity](/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") (PPP).[469]

The nominal GDP of the U.S. is estimated to be $17.528 trillion as of
2014[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit)[470]
From 1983 to 2008, U.S. real compounded annual GDP growth was 3.3%, compared
to a 2.3% weighted average for the rest of the [G7](/wiki/G7 "G7").[471] The
country ranks ninth in the world in [nominal GDP per
capita](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(nominal\)_per_capita "List of
countries by GDP \(nominal\) per capita") (first in the Americas)[33][32] and
sixth in [GDP per capita at
PPP](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(PPP\)_per_capita "List of countries by
GDP \(PPP\) per capita").[469] The [U.S. dollar](/wiki/United_States_dollar
"United States dollar") is the world's primary [reserve
currency](/wiki/Reserve_currency "Reserve currency").[472] The U.S. economy is
also the fastest growing in the Americas.[33][32]

The United States is the [largest importer](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports
"List of countries by imports") of goods and [second-largest
exporter](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports "List of countries by exports"),
though [exports per capita](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports_per_capita
"List of countries by exports per capita") are relatively low. In 2010, the
total [U.S. trade deficit](/wiki/Foreign_trade_of_the_United_States "Foreign
trade of the United States") was $635 billion.[473] [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada"), [China](/wiki/China "China"), [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"),
[Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"), and [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") are its
top trading partners.[474] In 2010, oil was the largest import commodity,
while transportation equipment was the country's largest export.[473] Japan is
the largest foreign holder of U.S. public debt.[475] The largest holder of the
U.S. debt are American entities, including federal government accounts and the
[Federal Reserve](/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System "Federal Reserve System"), who
hold the majority of the debt.[476][477][478][479][fn 15]

In 2009, the private sector was estimated to constitute 86.4% of the economy,
with federal government activity accounting for 4.3% and state and local
government activity (including federal transfers) the remaining 9.3%.[482] The
number of employees at all levels of government outnumber those in
[manufacturing](/wiki/Manufacturing_in_the_United_States "Manufacturing in the
United States") by 1.7 to 1.[483] While its economy has reached a
[postindustrial](/wiki/Post-industrial_society "Post-industrial society")
level of development and its [service
sector](/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy "Tertiary sector of the economy")
constitutes 67.8% of GDP, the United States remains an industrial power.[484]
The leading business field by gross business receipts is wholesale and retail
trade; by net income it is manufacturing.[485] In the
[franchising](/wiki/Franchising "Franchising") business model,
[McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") and
[Subway](/wiki/Subway_\(restaurant\) "Subway \(restaurant\)") are the two most
recognized brands in the world. [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola") is
the most recognized [soft drink](/wiki/Soft_drink "Soft drink") company in the
world.[486]

Chemical products are the leading manufacturing field.[487] The United States
is the largest producer of oil in the world, as well as its second-largest
importer.[488] It is the world's number one producer of electrical and nuclear
energy, as well as [liquid natural gas](/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas "Liquefied
natural gas"), [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur "Sulfur"), phosphates, and
[salt](/wiki/Salt "Salt"). The [National Mining
Association](/wiki/National_Mining_Association "National Mining Association")
provides data pertaining to [coal](/wiki/Coal "Coal") and
[minerals](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") that include [beryllium](/wiki/Beryllium
"Beryllium"), [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper"), [lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead"),
[magnesium](/wiki/Magnesium "Magnesium"), [zinc](/wiki/Zinc "Zinc"),
[titanium](/wiki/Titanium "Titanium") and others.[489][490]

[Agriculture](/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_United_States "Agriculture in the
United States") accounts for just under 1% of GDP,[484] yet the United States
is the world's top producer of corn[491] and soybeans.[492] The [National
Agricultural Statistics
Service](/wiki/National_Agricultural_Statistics_Service "National Agricultural
Statistics Service") maintains agricultural statistics for products that
include [peanuts](/wiki/Peanut "Peanut"), [oats](/wiki/Oat "Oat"),
[rye](/wiki/Rye "Rye"), [wheat](/wiki/Wheat "Wheat"), [rice](/wiki/Rice
"Rice"), [cotton](/wiki/Cotton "Cotton"), [corn](/wiki/Maize "Maize"),
[barley](/wiki/Barley "Barley"), [hay](/wiki/Hay "Hay"),
[sunflowers](/wiki/Helianthus "Helianthus"), and
[oilseeds](/wiki/Vegetable_oil "Vegetable oil"). In addition, the [United
States Department of
Agriculture](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture "United States
Department of Agriculture") (USDA) provides livestock statistics regarding
[beef](/wiki/Beef "Beef"), [poultry](/wiki/Poultry "Poultry"),
[pork](/wiki/Pork "Pork"), and [dairy products](/wiki/Milk "Milk"). The
country is the primary developer and grower of [genetically modified
food](/wiki/Genetically_modified_food "Genetically modified food"),
representing half of the world's biotech [crops](/wiki/Crops "Crops").[493]

[Consumer spending](/wiki/Consumer_spending "Consumer spending") comprises 68%
of the U.S. economy in 2015.[494] In August 2010, the American labor force
consisted of 154.1 million people. With 21.2 million people, government is the
leading field of employment. The largest private employment sector is health
care and social assistance, with 16.4 million people. About 12% of workers are
[unionized](/wiki/Labor_unions_in_the_United_States "Labor unions in the
United States"), compared to 30% in [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe
"Western Europe").[495] The World Bank ranks the United States first in the
ease of hiring and firing workers.[496] The United States is ranked among the
top three in the [Global Competitiveness
Report](/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report "Global Competitiveness Report")
as well. It has a smaller [welfare state](/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state")
and redistributes less income through government action than European nations
tend to.[497]

The United States is the only advanced economy that does not [guarantee its
workers paid
vacation](/wiki/List_of_statutory_minimum_employment_leave_by_country "List of
statutory minimum employment leave by country")[498] and is one of just a few
countries in the world without [paid family leave](/wiki/Paid_family_leave
"Paid family leave") as a legal right, with the others being [Papua New
Guinea](/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea "Papua New Guinea"), [Suriname](/wiki/Suriname
"Suriname") and [Liberia](/wiki/Liberia "Liberia").[499] While federal law
currently does not require sick leave, it is a common benefit for government
workers and full-time employees at corporations.[500] 74% of full-time
American workers get paid sick leave, according to the Bureau of Labor
Statistics, although only 24% of part-time workers get the same benefits.[500]
In 2009, the United States had the third-highest [workforce
productivity](/wiki/Workforce_productivity "Workforce productivity") per
person in the world, behind [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg "Luxembourg") and
[Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway"). It was fourth in productivity per hour,
behind those two countries and the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands
"Netherlands").[501]

The [2008–2012 global recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession")
significantly affected the United States, with output still below potential
according to the [Congressional Budget
Office](/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office "Congressional Budget Office").[502]
It brought high [unemployment](/wiki/Unemployment "Unemployment") (which has
been decreasing but remains above pre-recession levels), along with low
[consumer confidence](/wiki/Consumer_confidence_index "Consumer confidence
index"), the [continuing decline in home values and increase in foreclosures
and personal bankruptcies](/wiki/United_States_housing_bubble "United States
housing bubble"), an escalating federal debt crisis,
[inflation](/wiki/Inflation "Inflation"), and [rising petroleum and food
prices](/wiki/2000s_energy_crisis "2000s energy crisis").

### Income, poverty and wealth

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg/220px-
South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:South_San_Jose_\(crop\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:South_San_Jose_\(crop\).jpg "Enlarge")

A [tract housing](/wiki/Tract_housing "Tract housing") development in [San
Jose, California](/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California")

Further information: [Income in the United
States](/wiki/Income_in_the_United_States "Income in the United States"),
[Poverty in the United States](/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States "Poverty in
the United States"), [Affluence in the United
States](/wiki/Affluence_in_the_United_States "Affluence in the United
States"), [United States counties by per capita
income](/wiki/United_States_counties_by_per_capita_income "United States
counties by per capita income"), and [Income inequality in the United
States](/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States "Income inequality in the
United States")

Americans have the highest average [household](/wiki/Household_income
"Household income") and [employee](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage
"List of countries by average wage") income among OECD nations, and in 2007
had the second-highest [median household income](/wiki/Median_household_income
"Median household income").[503][504][505] According to the Census Bureau,
median household income was $59,039 in 2016. [506] Accounting for 4.4% of the
global population, Americans collectively possess 41.6% of the world's total
wealth,[507] and Americans make up roughly half of the world's population of
millionaires.[508] The [Global Food Security
Index](/wiki/Global_Food_Security_Index "Global Food Security Index") ranked
the U.S. number one for food affordability and overall food security in March
2013.[509] Americans on average have over twice as much living space per
dwelling and per person as [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European
Union") residents, and more than every EU nation.[510] For 2013 the [United
Nations Development Programme](/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme
"United Nations Development Programme") ranked the United States 5th among 187
countries in its [Human Development
Index](/wiki/Human_Development_Index#2014_report "Human Development Index")
and 28th in its [inequality-adjusted
HDI](/wiki/Human_Development_Index#Inequality-adjusted_HDI "Human Development
Index") (IHDI).[511]

After years of stagnant growth, in 2016, according to the Census, median
household income reached a record high after two consecutive years of record
growth, although income inequality remains at record highs with top fifth of
earners taking home more than half of all overall income.[512] There has been
a widening gap between productivity and median incomes since the 1970s.[513]
However, the gap between total compensation and productivity is not as wide
because of increased employee benefits such as health insurance.[514] The rise
in the share of total annual income received by the top 1 percent, which has
more than doubled from 9 percent in 1976 to 20 percent in 2011, has
significantly affected [income
inequality](/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States "Income inequality in
the United States"),[515] leaving the United States with one of the widest
income distributions among OECD nations.[516] The [top 1 percent of income-
earners](/wiki/Upper_class "Upper class") accounted for 52 percent of the
income gains from 2009 to 2015, where income is defined as market income
excluding government transfers,[517] The extent and relevance of income
inequality is a matter of
debate.[518][_[disputed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Disputed statement") –
[discuss](/wiki/Talk:United_States#Trends_in_local_vs_global_inequality
"Talk:United States")_][519]

**United States ' families median net worth** source: Fed Survey of Consumer Finances[520] in 2013 dollars | 1998 | 2013 | change  
---|---|---|---  
All families | $102,500 | $81,200 | -20.8%  
Bottom 20% of incomes | $8,300 | $6,100 | -26.5%  
2nd lowest 20% of incomes | $47,400 | $22,400 | -52.7%  
Middle 20% of incomes | $76,300 | $61,700 | -19.1%  
Top 10% | $646,600 | $1,130,700 | +74.9%  
  
[Wealth](/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States "Wealth in the United States"),
like income and taxes, is [highly
concentrated](/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_the_United_States "Wealth inequality
in the United States"); the richest 10% of the adult population possess 72% of
the country's household wealth, while the bottom half claim only 2%.[521]
According to a September 2017 report by the Federal Reserve, the top 1%
controlled 38.6% of the country's wealth in 2016.[522] Between June 2007 and
November 2008 the [global recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession")
led to falling asset prices around the world. Assets owned by Americans lost
about a quarter of their value.[523] Since peaking in the second quarter of
2007, household wealth was down $14 trillion, but has since increased $14
trillion over 2006 levels.[524][525] At the end of 2014, [household
debt](/wiki/Household_debt "Household debt") amounted to $11.8 trillion,[526]
down from $13.8 trillion at the end of 2008.[527]

There were about 578,424 sheltered and unsheltered [homeless persons in the
U.S.](/wiki/Homelessness_in_the_United_States "Homelessness in the United
States") in January 2014, with almost two-thirds staying in an emergency
shelter or transitional housing program.[528] In 2011 [16.7 million children
lived in food-insecure households](/wiki/Hunger_in_the_United_States#Children
"Hunger in the United States"), about 35% more than 2007 levels, though only
1.1% of U.S. children, or 845,000, saw reduced food intake or disrupted eating
patterns at some point during the year, and most cases were not chronic.[529]
According to a 2014 report by the Census Bureau, one in five young adults
lives in [poverty](/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States "Poverty in the United
States") today, up from one in seven in 1980.[530]

## Infrastructure

### Transportation

Main article: [Transportation in the United
States](/wiki/Transportation_in_the_United_States "Transportation in the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Map_of_current_Interstates.svg/220px-
Map_of_current_Interstates.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Map_of_current_Interstates.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_current_Interstates.svg "Enlarge")

The [Interstate Highway System](/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System "Interstate
Highway System"), which extends 46,876 miles (75,440 km).[531]

Personal transportation is dominated by automobiles, which operate on a
network of 4 million miles (6.4 million km) of public roads,[532] including
one of the world's [longest highway
systems](/wiki/National_Highway_System_\(United_States\) "National Highway
System \(United States\)") at 57,000 miles (91700 km).[533] The world's
second-largest automobile market,[534] the United States has the highest rate
of per-capita vehicle ownership in the world, with 765 vehicles per 1,000
Americans.[535] About 40% of [personal
vehicles](/wiki/Passenger_vehicles_in_the_United_States "Passenger vehicles in
the United States") are vans, [SUVs](/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle "Sport
utility vehicle"), or light trucks.[536] The average American adult
(accounting for all drivers and non-drivers) spends 55 minutes driving every
day, traveling 29 miles (47 km).[537]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg/220px-
High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg.png)](/wiki/File:High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg)

[](/wiki/File:High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg "Enlarge")

Map showing current [rail speeds](/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_the_United_States
"High-speed rail in the United States") in the United States.[538]

[Mass transit accounts for 9% of total U.S. work
trips](/wiki/Mass_transit_in_the_United_States "Mass transit in the United
States").[539][540] [Transport of goods by
rail](/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_United_States "Rail transportation in
the United States") is extensive, though relatively low numbers of passengers
(approximately 31 million annually) use intercity rail to travel, partly
because of the low population density throughout much of the U.S.
interior.[541][542] However, ridership on [Amtrak](/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak"), the
national intercity passenger [rail
system](/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_United_States "Rail transportation in
the United States"), grew by almost 37% between 2000 and 2010.[543] Also,
[light rail development](/wiki/Light_rail_in_the_United_States "Light rail in
the United States") has increased in recent years.[544] Bicycle usage for work
commutes is minimal.[545]

The [civil airline industry](/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_the_United_States "List
of airlines of the United States") is entirely privately owned and has been
largely [deregulated since 1978](/wiki/Airline_Deregulation_Act "Airline
Deregulation Act"), while [most major
airports](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_the_United_States "List of airports in the
United States") are publicly owned.[546] The three largest airlines in the
world by passengers carried are U.S.-based; [American
Airlines](/wiki/American_Airlines "American Airlines") is number one after its
2013 acquisition by [US Airways](/wiki/US_Airways "US Airways").[547] Of the
[world's 50 busiest passenger
airports](/wiki/List_of_the_world%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic
"List of the world's busiest airports by passenger traffic"), 16 are in the
United States, including the busiest, [Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta
International
Airport](/wiki/Hartsfield%E2%80%93Jackson_Atlanta_International_Airport
"Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport"), and the fourth-busiest,
[O'Hare International Airport](/wiki/O%27Hare_International_Airport "O'Hare
International Airport") in [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago").[548] In the
aftermath of the [9/11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11
attacks") of 2001, the [Transportation Security
Administration](/wiki/Transportation_Security_Administration "Transportation
Security Administration") was created to police airports and commercial
airliners.

### Energy

Further information: [Energy policy of the United
States](/wiki/Energy_policy_of_the_United_States "Energy policy of the United
States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg/220px-
UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg)](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg "Enlarge")

The U.S. power transmission grid consists of about 300,000 km (190,000 mi) of
lines operated by approximately 500 companies. The [North American Electric
Reliability Corporation](/wiki/North_American_Electric_Reliability_Corporation
"North American Electric Reliability Corporation") (NERC) oversees all of
them.

The [United States energy](/wiki/Energy_in_the_United_States "Energy in the
United States") market is about 29,000 [terawatt hours](/wiki/Kilowatt_hour
"Kilowatt hour") per year.[549] [Energy consumption per
capita](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_energy_consumption_per_capita "List of
countries by energy consumption per capita") is 7.8 tons (7076 kg) of oil
equivalent per year, the 10th-highest rate in the world. In 2005, 40% of this
energy came from petroleum, 23% from coal, and 22% from natural gas. The
remainder was supplied by nuclear power and [renewable
energy](/wiki/Renewable_energy "Renewable energy") sources.[550] The United
States is the world's largest consumer of petroleum.[551]The United States has
27% of global coal reserves.[552] It is the world's largest producer of
natural gas and crude oil.[553]

For decades, [nuclear power](/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_the_United_States "Nuclear
power in the United States") has played a limited role relative to many other
developed countries, in part because of public perception in the wake of a
[1979 accident](/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident "Three Mile Island
accident"). In 2007, several applications for new nuclear plants were
filed.[554]

### Water supply and sanitation

Main article: [Drinking water supply and sanitation in the United
States](/wiki/Drinking_water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_United_States
"Drinking water supply and sanitation in the United States")

Issues that affect water supply in the United States include droughts in the
West, [water scarcity](/wiki/Water_scarcity "Water scarcity"),
[pollution](/wiki/Water_pollution_in_the_United_States "Water pollution in the
United States"), a backlog of investment, concerns about the affordability of
water for the poorest, and a rapidly retiring workforce. Increased variability
and intensity of rainfall as a result of [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change
"Climate change") is expected to produce both more severe droughts and
flooding, with potentially serious consequences for water supply and for
pollution from [combined sewer overflows](/wiki/Combined_sewer_overflow
"Combined sewer overflow").[555][556][fn 16]

## Education

Main article: [Education in the United
States](/wiki/Education_in_the_United_States "Education in the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/University-of-
Virginia-Rotunda.jpg/220px-University-of-Virginia-
Rotunda.jpg)](/wiki/File:University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg "Enlarge")

The [University of Virginia](/wiki/University_of_Virginia "University of
Virginia"), founded by [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas
Jefferson") in 1819, is one of the many public universities in the United
States. Universal government-funded education exists in the United States,
while there are also many privately funded institutions.

American [public education](/wiki/State_school "State school") is operated by
state and local governments, regulated by the [United States Department of
Education](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Education "United States
Department of Education") through restrictions on federal grants. In most
states, children are required to attend school from the age of six or seven
(generally, [kindergarten](/wiki/Kindergarten "Kindergarten") or [first
grade](/wiki/First_grade "First grade")) until they turn 18 (generally
bringing them through [twelfth grade](/wiki/Twelfth_grade "Twelfth grade"),
the end of [high school](/wiki/High_school "High school")); some states allow
students to leave school at 16 or 17.[559]

About 12% of children are enrolled in [parochial](/wiki/Parochial_school
"Parochial school") or [nonsectarian](/wiki/Nonsectarian "Nonsectarian")
[private schools](/wiki/Private_school "Private school"). Just over 2% of
children are [homeschooled](/wiki/Homeschooling "Homeschooling").[560] The
U.S. spends more on education per student than any nation in the world,
spending more than $11,000 per elementary student in 2010 and more than
$12,000 per high school student.[561] Some 80% of U.S. college students attend
[public universities](/wiki/Public_university "Public university").[562]

The United States has many competitive private and public [institutions of
higher education](/wiki/Lists_of_American_institutions_of_higher_education
"Lists of American institutions of higher education"). The majority of the
world's top universities listed by different ranking organizations are in the
U.S.[563][564][565] There are also local [community
colleges](/wiki/Community_college "Community college") with generally more
open admission policies, shorter academic programs, and lower tuition. Of
Americans 25 and older, 84.6% graduated from high school, 52.6% attended some
college, 27.2% earned a [bachelor's degree](/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree
"Bachelor's degree"), and 9.6% earned graduate degrees.[566] The basic
[literacy](/wiki/Literacy "Literacy") rate is approximately 99%.[225][567] The
United Nations assigns the United States an Education Index of 0.97, tying it
for 12th in the world.[568]

As for public expenditures on higher education, the U.S. trails some other
[OECD](/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development
"Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development") nations but spends
more per student than the OECD average, and more than all nations in combined
public and private spending.[561][569] As of
2012[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit),
[student loan debt](/wiki/Student_debt "Student debt") exceeded one trillion
dollars, more than Americans owe on credit cards.[570]

## Culture

Main article: [Culture of the United
States](/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States "Culture of the United States")

See also: [Alaska Natives § Cultures](/wiki/Alaska_Natives#Cultures "Alaska
Natives"), [Native American cultures in the United
States](/wiki/Native_American_cultures_in_the_United_States "Native American
cultures in the United States"), [Culture of the Native
Hawaiians](/wiki/Culture_of_the_Native_Hawaiians "Culture of the Native
Hawaiians"), [Social class in the United
States](/wiki/Social_class_in_the_United_States "Social class in the United
States"), [Public holidays in the United
States](/wiki/Public_holidays_in_the_United_States "Public holidays in the
United States"), and [Tourism in the United
States](/wiki/Tourism_in_the_United_States "Tourism in the United States")

The United States is home to [many cultures](/wiki/Multiculturalism
"Multiculturalism") and a wide variety of ethnic groups, traditions, and
values.[571][572] Aside from the [Native
American](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the
United States"), [Native Hawaiian](/wiki/Native_Hawaiians "Native Hawaiians"),
and [Native Alaskan](/wiki/Alaska_Natives "Alaska Natives") populations,
nearly all Americans or their ancestors settled or immigrated within the past
five centuries.[573] Mainstream American culture is a [Western
culture](/wiki/Western_culture "Western culture") largely derived from the
[traditions of European immigrants](/wiki/European_American "European
American") with influences from many other sources, such as [traditions
brought by slaves from Africa](/wiki/African-American_culture "African-
American culture").[571][574] More recent immigration from
[Asia](/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American") and especially [Latin
America](/wiki/Latin_American_culture "Latin American culture") has added to a
cultural mix that has been described as both a homogenizing [melting
pot](/wiki/Melting_pot "Melting pot"), and a heterogeneous [salad
bowl](/wiki/Salad_bowl_\(cultural_idea\) "Salad bowl \(cultural idea\)") in
which immigrants and their descendants retain distinctive cultural
characteristics.[571]

Core American culture was established by [Protestant](/wiki/Protestantism
"Protestantism") British colonists and shaped by the [frontier](/wiki/Frontier
"Frontier") settlement process, with the traits derived passed down to
descendants and transmitted to immigrants through assimilation. Americans have
traditionally been characterized by a strong [work ethic](/wiki/Work_ethic
"Work ethic"), competitiveness, and individualism,[575] as well as a unifying
belief in an "American [creed](/wiki/Creed "Creed")" emphasizing liberty,
equality, private property, democracy, rule of law, and a preference for
limited government.[576] Americans are extremely charitable by global
standards. According to a 2006 British study, Americans gave 1.67% of GDP to
charity, more than any other nation studied, more than twice the second place
British figure of 0.73%, and around twelve times the French figure of
0.14%.[577][578]

The [American Dream](/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream"), or the perception
that Americans enjoy high [social mobility](/wiki/Socio-
economic_mobility_in_the_United_States "Socio-economic mobility in the United
States"), plays a key role in attracting immigrants.[579] Whether this
perception is realistic has been a topic of
debate.[580][581][582][583][471][584] While mainstream culture holds that the
United States is a [classless society](/wiki/Classless_society "Classless
society"),[585] scholars identify significant differences between the
country's social classes, affecting [socialization](/wiki/Socialization
"Socialization"), language, and values.[586] Americans' self-images, social
viewpoints, and cultural expectations are associated with their occupations to
an unusually close degree.[587] While Americans tend greatly to value
socioeconomic achievement, being [ordinary or average](/wiki/Average_Joe
"Average Joe") is generally seen as a positive attribute.[588]

### Food

Main article: [Cuisine of the United
States](/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States "Cuisine of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg/220px-
Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg)](/wiki/File:Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg "Enlarge")

[Apple pie](/wiki/Apple_pie "Apple pie") is a food commonly associated with
American cuisine.

Mainstream American cuisine is similar to that in other Western countries.
[Wheat](/wiki/Wheat "Wheat") is the primary cereal grain with about three-
quarters of grain products made of wheat flour[589] and many dishes use
indigenous ingredients, such as turkey, venison, potatoes, sweet potatoes,
corn, squash, and maple syrup which were consumed by Native Americans and
early European settlers.[590] These home grown foods are part of a shared
national menu on one of America's most popular holidays;
[Thanksgiving](/wiki/Thanksgiving_\(United_States\) "Thanksgiving \(United
States\)"), when some Americans make traditional foods to celebrate the
occasion.[591]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Roast_turkey.jpg/220px-
Roast_turkey.jpg)](/wiki/File:Roast_turkey.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Roast_turkey.jpg "Enlarge")

Roasted [turkey](/wiki/Turkey_\(bird\) "Turkey \(bird\)") is a traditional
menu item of an American [Thanksgiving](/wiki/Thanksgiving_\(United_States\)
"Thanksgiving \(United States\)") dinner.[592]

Characteristic dishes such as apple pie, fried chicken, pizza, hamburgers, and
hot dogs derive from the recipes of various immigrants. French fries,
[Mexican](/wiki/Mexican_cuisine "Mexican cuisine") dishes such as burritos and
tacos, and pasta dishes freely adapted from [Italian](/wiki/Italian_cuisine
"Italian cuisine") sources are widely consumed.[593] Americans drink three
times as much coffee as tea.[594] Marketing by U.S. industries is largely
responsible for making orange juice and milk ubiquitous
[breakfast](/wiki/Breakfast "Breakfast") beverages.[595][596]

American eating habits owe a great deal to that of their [British
culinary](/wiki/British_cuisine "British cuisine") roots with some variations.
Although American lands could grow newer vegetables that Britain could not,
most colonists would not eat these new foods until accepted by Europeans.[597]
Over time American foods changed to a point that food critic, [John L.
Hess](/wiki/John_L._Hess "John L. Hess") stated in 1972: _" Our founding
fathers were as far superior to our present political leaders in the quality
of their food as they were in the quality of their prose and
intelligence"_.[598]

The American [fast food](/wiki/Fast_food "Fast food") industry, the world's
largest,[599] pioneered the [drive-through](/wiki/Drive-through "Drive-
through") format in the 1940s.[600] Fast food consumption has sparked health
concerns. During the 1980s and 1990s, Americans' caloric intake rose 24%;[593]
frequent dining at fast food outlets is associated with what public health
officials call the American "[obesity
epidemic](/wiki/Obesity_in_the_United_States "Obesity in the United
States")".[601] Highly sweetened soft drinks are widely popular, and sugared
beverages account for nine percent of American caloric intake.[602]

### Literature, philosophy, and the arts

Main articles: [American literature](/wiki/American_literature "American
literature"), [American philosophy](/wiki/American_philosophy "American
philosophy"), [Architecture of the United
States](/wiki/Architecture_of_the_United_States "Architecture of the United
States"), [Visual art of the United
States](/wiki/Visual_art_of_the_United_States "Visual art of the United
States"), and [American classical music](/wiki/American_classical_music
"American classical music")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-
Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg/170px-
Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-
Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mark_Twain,_Brady-
Handy_photo_portrait,_Feb_7,_1871,_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mark_Twain,_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait,_Feb_7,_1871,_cropped.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Mark Twain](/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain"), American author and
[humorist](/wiki/Comedy "Comedy").

In the 18th and early 19th centuries, American art and literature took most of
its cues from Europe. Writers such as [Nathaniel
Hawthorne](/wiki/Nathaniel_Hawthorne "Nathaniel Hawthorne"), [Edgar Allan
Poe](/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe "Edgar Allan Poe"), and [Henry David
Thoreau](/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau "Henry David Thoreau") established a
distinctive American literary voice by the middle of the 19th century. [Mark
Twain](/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain") and poet [Walt
Whitman](/wiki/Walt_Whitman "Walt Whitman") were major figures in the
century's second half; [Emily Dickinson](/wiki/Emily_Dickinson "Emily
Dickinson"), virtually unknown during her lifetime, is now recognized as an
essential American poet.[603] A work seen as capturing fundamental aspects of
the national experience and character—such as [Herman
Melville](/wiki/Herman_Melville "Herman Melville")'s _[Moby-Dick](/wiki/Moby-
Dick "Moby-Dick")_ (1851), Twain's _[The Adventures of Huckleberry
Finn](/wiki/Adventures_of_Huckleberry_Finn "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn")_
(1885), [F. Scott Fitzgerald](/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald "F. Scott
Fitzgerald")'s _[The Great Gatsby](/wiki/The_Great_Gatsby "The Great Gatsby")_
(1925) and [Harper Lee](/wiki/Harper_Lee "Harper Lee")'s _[To Kill a
Mockingbird](/wiki/To_Kill_a_Mockingbird "To Kill a Mockingbird")_ (1960)—may
be dubbed the "[Great American Novel](/wiki/Great_American_Novel "Great
American Novel")".[604]

Twelve U.S. citizens have won the [Nobel Prize in
Literature](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature"), most
recently [Bob Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan") in 2016. [William
Faulkner](/wiki/William_Faulkner "William Faulkner"), [Ernest
Hemingway](/wiki/Ernest_Hemingway "Ernest Hemingway") and [John
Steinbeck](/wiki/John_Steinbeck "John Steinbeck") are often named among the
most influential writers of the 20th century.[605] Popular literary genres
such as the [Western](/wiki/Western_fiction "Western fiction") and
[hardboiled](/wiki/Hardboiled "Hardboiled") crime fiction developed in the
United States. The [Beat Generation](/wiki/Beat_Generation "Beat Generation")
writers opened up new literary approaches, as have
[postmodernist](/wiki/Postmodern_literature "Postmodern literature") authors
such as [John Barth](/wiki/John_Barth "John Barth"), [Thomas
Pynchon](/wiki/Thomas_Pynchon "Thomas Pynchon"), and [Don
DeLillo](/wiki/Don_DeLillo "Don DeLillo").[606]

The [transcendentalists](/wiki/Transcendentalism "Transcendentalism"), led by
Thoreau and [Ralph Waldo Emerson](/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson "Ralph Waldo
Emerson"), established the first major [American philosophical
movement](/wiki/American_philosophy "American philosophy"). After the Civil
War, [Charles Sanders Peirce](/wiki/Charles_Sanders_Peirce "Charles Sanders
Peirce") and then [William James](/wiki/William_James "William James") and
[John Dewey](/wiki/John_Dewey "John Dewey") were leaders in the development of
[pragmatism](/wiki/Pragmatism "Pragmatism"). In the 20th century, the work of
[W. V. O. Quine](/wiki/Willard_Van_Orman_Quine "Willard Van Orman Quine") and
[Richard Rorty](/wiki/Richard_Rorty "Richard Rorty"), and later [Noam
Chomsky](/wiki/Noam_Chomsky "Noam Chomsky"), brought [analytic
philosophy](/wiki/Analytic_philosophy "Analytic philosophy") to the fore of
American philosophical academia. [John Rawls](/wiki/John_Rawls "John Rawls")
and [Robert Nozick](/wiki/Robert_Nozick "Robert Nozick") led a revival of
[political philosophy](/wiki/Political_philosophy "Political philosophy").
[Cornel West](/wiki/Cornel_West "Cornel West") and [Judith
Butler](/wiki/Judith_Butler "Judith Butler") have led a continental tradition
in American philosophical academia. [Chicago school
economists](/wiki/Chicago_school_of_economics "Chicago school of economics")
like [Milton Friedman](/wiki/Milton_Friedman "Milton Friedman"), [James M.
Buchanan](/wiki/James_M._Buchanan "James M. Buchanan"), and [Thomas
Sowell](/wiki/Thomas_Sowell "Thomas Sowell") have affected various fields in
social and political philosophy.[607][608]

In the visual arts, the [Hudson River School](/wiki/Hudson_River_School
"Hudson River School") was a mid-19th-century movement in the tradition of
European [naturalism](/wiki/Realism_\(arts\) "Realism \(arts\)"). The realist
paintings of [Thomas Eakins](/wiki/Thomas_Eakins "Thomas Eakins") are now
widely celebrated. The 1913 [Armory Show](/wiki/Armory_Show "Armory Show") in
New York City, an exhibition of European [modernist art](/wiki/Modern_art
"Modern art"), shocked the public and transformed the U.S. art scene.[609]
[Georgia O'Keeffe](/wiki/Georgia_O%27Keeffe "Georgia O'Keeffe"), [Marsden
Hartley](/wiki/Marsden_Hartley "Marsden Hartley"), and others experimented
with new, individualistic styles. Major artistic movements such as the
[abstract expressionism](/wiki/Abstract_expressionism "Abstract
expressionism") of [Jackson Pollock](/wiki/Jackson_Pollock "Jackson Pollock")
and [Willem de Kooning](/wiki/Willem_de_Kooning "Willem de Kooning") and the
[pop art](/wiki/Pop_art "Pop art") of [Andy Warhol](/wiki/Andy_Warhol "Andy
Warhol") and [Roy Lichtenstein](/wiki/Roy_Lichtenstein "Roy Lichtenstein")
developed largely in the United States. The tide of modernism and then
[postmodernism](/wiki/Postmodernism "Postmodernism") has brought fame to
American architects such as [Frank Lloyd Wright](/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright
"Frank Lloyd Wright"), [Philip Johnson](/wiki/Philip_Johnson "Philip
Johnson"), and [Frank Gehry](/wiki/Frank_Gehry "Frank Gehry").[610] Americans
have long been important in the modern artistic medium of
[photography](/wiki/Photography "Photography"), with major photographers
including [Alfred Stieglitz](/wiki/Alfred_Stieglitz "Alfred Stieglitz"),
[Edward Steichen](/wiki/Edward_Steichen "Edward Steichen"), and [Ansel
Adams](/wiki/Ansel_Adams "Ansel Adams").[611]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Times_Square_1-2.JPG/220px-
Times_Square_1-2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Times_Square_1-2.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Times_Square_1-2.JPG "Enlarge")

[Times Square](/wiki/Times_Square "Times Square") in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), the hub of the [Broadway
theater](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre")
[district](/wiki/Theater_District,_Manhattan "Theater District,
Manhattan")[612]

One of the first major promoters of [American
theater](/wiki/Theater_of_the_United_States "Theater of the United States")
was impresario [P. T. Barnum](/wiki/P._T._Barnum "P. T. Barnum"), who began
operating a lower [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") entertainment
complex in 1841. The team of [Harrigan and Hart](/wiki/Edward_Harrigan "Edward
Harrigan") produced a series of popular [musical](/wiki/Musical_theatre
"Musical theatre") comedies in New York starting in the late 1870s. In the
20th century, the modern musical form emerged on
[Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre"); the songs of musical
theater composers such as [Irving Berlin](/wiki/Irving_Berlin "Irving
Berlin"), [Cole Porter](/wiki/Cole_Porter "Cole Porter"), and [Stephen
Sondheim](/wiki/Stephen_Sondheim "Stephen Sondheim") have become [pop
standards](/wiki/Traditional_pop_music "Traditional pop music"). Playwright
[Eugene O'Neill](/wiki/Eugene_O%27Neill "Eugene O'Neill") won the Nobel
literature prize in 1936; other acclaimed U.S. dramatists include multiple
[Pulitzer Prize](/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Drama "Pulitzer Prize for Drama")
winners [Tennessee Williams](/wiki/Tennessee_Williams "Tennessee Williams"),
[Edward Albee](/wiki/Edward_Albee "Edward Albee"), and [August
Wilson](/wiki/August_Wilson "August Wilson").[613]

Though little known at the time, [Charles Ives](/wiki/Charles_Ives "Charles
Ives")'s work of the 1910s established him as the first major U.S. composer in
the classical tradition, while experimentalists such as [Henry
Cowell](/wiki/Henry_Cowell "Henry Cowell") and [John Cage](/wiki/John_Cage
"John Cage") created a distinctive American approach to classical composition.
[Aaron Copland](/wiki/Aaron_Copland "Aaron Copland") and [George
Gershwin](/wiki/George_Gershwin "George Gershwin") developed a new synthesis
of popular and classical music.

[Choreographers](/wiki/Choreography "Choreography") [Isadora
Duncan](/wiki/Isadora_Duncan "Isadora Duncan") and [Martha
Graham](/wiki/Martha_Graham "Martha Graham") helped create [modern
dance](/wiki/Modern_dance "Modern dance"), while [George
Balanchine](/wiki/George_Balanchine "George Balanchine") and [Jerome
Robbins](/wiki/Jerome_Robbins "Jerome Robbins") were leaders in 20th-century
ballet.

### Music

Main article: [Music of the United States](/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States
"Music of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg/220px-
Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg)](/wiki/File:Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Grammy Award](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award") is awarded to leading
music artists.

The rhythmic and lyrical styles of [African-American music](/wiki/African-
American_music "African-American music") have deeply influenced [American
music](/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States "Music of the United States") at
large, distinguishing it from European traditions. Elements from
[folk](/wiki/Folk_music "Folk music") idioms such as the [blues](/wiki/Blues
"Blues") and what is now known as [old-time music](/wiki/Old-time_music "Old-
time music") were adopted and transformed into [popular
genres](/wiki/Popular_music "Popular music") with global audiences.
[Jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") was developed by innovators such as [Louis
Armstrong](/wiki/Louis_Armstrong "Louis Armstrong") and [Duke
Ellington](/wiki/Duke_Ellington "Duke Ellington") early in the 20th century.
[Country music](/wiki/Country_music "Country music") developed in the 1920s,
and [rhythm and blues](/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues "Rhythm and blues") in the
1940s.[614]

[Elvis Presley](/wiki/Elvis_Presley "Elvis Presley") and [Chuck
Berry](/wiki/Chuck_Berry "Chuck Berry") were among the mid-1950s pioneers of
[rock and roll](/wiki/Rock_and_roll "Rock and roll"). In the 1960s, [Bob
Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan") emerged from the [folk
revival](/wiki/American_folk_music_revival "American folk music revival") to
become one of America's most celebrated songwriters and [James
Brown](/wiki/James_Brown "James Brown") led the development of
[funk](/wiki/Funk "Funk"). More recent American creations include [hip
hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music") and [house music](/wiki/House_music
"House music"). American pop stars such as Presley, [Michael
Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael Jackson"), and
[Madonna](/wiki/Madonna_\(entertainer\) "Madonna \(entertainer\)") have become
global celebrities,[614] as have contemporary musical artists such as [Taylor
Swift](/wiki/Taylor_Swift "Taylor Swift"), [Britney
Spears](/wiki/Britney_Spears "Britney Spears"), [Katy Perry](/wiki/Katy_Perry
"Katy Perry"), and [Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9 "Beyoncé") as well as hip hop
artists [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z "Jay-Z"), [Eminem](/wiki/Eminem "Eminem") and
[Kanye West](/wiki/Kanye_West "Kanye West").[615] Rock bands such as
[Metallica](/wiki/Metallica "Metallica"), the [Eagles](/wiki/Eagles_\(band\)
"Eagles \(band\)"), and [Aerosmith](/wiki/Aerosmith "Aerosmith") are among the
[highest grossing](/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists "List of best-
selling music artists") in worldwide sales.[616][617][618]

### Cinema

Main article: [Cinema of the United States](/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States
"Cinema of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/HollywoodSign.jpg/220px-
HollywoodSign.jpg)](/wiki/File:HollywoodSign.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HollywoodSign.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Hollywood Sign](/wiki/Hollywood_Sign "Hollywood Sign") in [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), California

[Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood"), a northern district of [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), California, is one of the leaders
in motion picture production.[619] The world's first commercial motion picture
exhibition was given in New York City in 1894, using [Thomas
Edison](/wiki/Thomas_Edison "Thomas Edison")'s [Kinetoscope](/wiki/Kinetoscope
"Kinetoscope").[620] The next year saw the first commercial screening of a
projected film, also in New York, and the United States was in the forefront
of [sound film](/wiki/Sound_film "Sound film")'s development in the following
decades. Since the early 20th century, the U.S. film industry has largely been
based in and around Hollywood, although in the 21st century an increasing
number of films are not made there, and film companies have been subject to
the forces of globalization.[621]

Director [D. W. Griffith](/wiki/D._W._Griffith "D. W. Griffith"), the top
American [filmmaker](/wiki/Filmmaker "Filmmaker") during the silent film
period, was central to the development of [film grammar](/wiki/Film_grammar
"Film grammar"), and producer/entrepreneur [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney
"Walt Disney") was a leader in both [animated film](/wiki/Animation
"Animation") and movie [merchandising](/wiki/Merchandising
"Merchandising").[622] Directors such as [John Ford](/wiki/John_Ford "John
Ford") redefined the image of the American Old West and history, and, like
others such as [John Huston](/wiki/John_Huston "John Huston"), broadened the
possibilities of cinema with location shooting, with great influence on
subsequent directors. The industry enjoyed its golden years, in what is
commonly referred to as the "[Golden Age of
Hollywood](/wiki/Classical_Hollywood_cinema "Classical Hollywood cinema")",
from the early sound period until the early 1960s,[623] with screen actors
such as [John Wayne](/wiki/John_Wayne "John Wayne") and [Marilyn
Monroe](/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe "Marilyn Monroe") becoming iconic
figures.[624][625] In the 1970s, film directors such as [Martin
Scorsese](/wiki/Martin_Scorsese "Martin Scorsese"), [Francis Ford
Coppola](/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola "Francis Ford Coppola") and [Robert
Altman](/wiki/Robert_Altman "Robert Altman") were a vital component in what
became known as "[New Hollywood](/wiki/New_Hollywood "New Hollywood")" or the
"Hollywood Renaissance",[626] grittier films influenced by French and Italian
realist pictures of the [post-war period](/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II
"Aftermath of World War II").[627] Since, directors such as [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg"), [George
Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas") and [James
Cameron](/wiki/James_Cameron "James Cameron") have gained renown for their
blockbuster films, often characterized by high production costs, and in
return, high earnings at the box office, with Cameron's
_[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\) "Avatar \(2009 film\)")_ (2009) earning
more than $2 billion.[628]

Notable films topping the [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute")'s [AFI
100](/wiki/AFI_100 "AFI 100") list include [Orson Welles](/wiki/Orson_Welles
"Orson Welles")'s _[Citizen Kane](/wiki/Citizen_Kane "Citizen Kane")_ (1941),
which is frequently cited as the greatest film of all time,[629][630]
_[Casablanca](/wiki/Casablanca_\(film\) "Casablanca \(film\)")_ (1942), _[The
Godfather](/wiki/The_Godfather "The Godfather")_ (1972), _[Gone with the
Wind](/wiki/Gone_with_the_Wind_\(1939_film\) "Gone with the Wind \(1939
film\)")_ (1939), _[Lawrence of Arabia](/wiki/Lawrence_of_Arabia_\(film\)
"Lawrence of Arabia \(film\)")_ (1962), _[The Wizard of
Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz \(1939 film\)")_
(1939), _[The Graduate](/wiki/The_Graduate "The Graduate")_ (1967), _[On the
Waterfront](/wiki/On_the_Waterfront "On the Waterfront")_ (1954),
_[Schindler's List](/wiki/Schindler%27s_List "Schindler's List")_ (1993),
_[Singin' in the Rain](/wiki/Singin%27_in_the_Rain "Singin' in the Rain")_
(1952), _[It's a Wonderful Life](/wiki/It%27s_a_Wonderful_Life "It's a
Wonderful Life")_ (1946) and _[Sunset
Boulevard](/wiki/Sunset_Boulevard_\(film\) "Sunset Boulevard \(film\)")_
(1950).[631] The [Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards"),
popularly known as the Oscars, have been held annually by the [Academy of
Motion Picture Arts and
Sciences](/wiki/Academy_of_Motion_Picture_Arts_and_Sciences "Academy of Motion
Picture Arts and Sciences") since 1929,[632] and the [Golden Globe
Awards](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Awards "Golden Globe Awards") have been held
annually since January 1944.[633]

### Sports

Main article: [Sports in the United States](/wiki/Sports_in_the_United_States
"Sports in the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg/167px-
Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/David-ortiz-batters-
box.JPG/167px-David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG)](/wiki/File:David-ortiz-batters-
box.JPG)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg/167px-
Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg/167px-151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:151005-F-ZJ145-361_\(22030960390\).jpg)

Most popular American sports are [American football](/wiki/American_football
"American football"), [baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball"),
[basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") and [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey
"Ice hockey")[634]

[American football](/wiki/American_football "American football") is by several
measures the most popular spectator sport;[635] the [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") (NFL) has
the highest average attendance of any sports league in the world, and the
[Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl") is watched by millions globally.
[Baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball") has been regarded as the U.S. [national
sport](/wiki/National_sport "National sport") since the late 19th century,
with [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball") (MLB) being the top league. [Basketball](/wiki/Basketball
"Basketball") and [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") are the
country's next two [leading professional team
sports](/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada
"Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada"), with the
top leagues being the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") (NBA) and the [National Hockey
League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") (NHL). These
four major sports, when played professionally, each occupy a season at
different, but overlapping, times of the year. [College
football](/wiki/College_football "College football") and
[basketball](/wiki/College_basketball "College basketball") attract large
audiences.[636] In [soccer](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football"), the country hosted the [1994 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup"), the [men's national
soccer team](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United States
men's national soccer team") qualified for ten World Cups and the [women's
team](/wiki/United_States_women%27s_national_soccer_team "United States
women's national soccer team") has won the [FIFA Women's World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA Women's World Cup") three times;
[Major League Soccer](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major League Soccer") is the
sport's highest league in the United States (featuring 19 American and 3
Canadian teams). The market for professional sports in the United States is
roughly $69 billion, roughly 50% larger than that of all of Europe, the Middle
East, and Africa combined.[637]

Eight [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games") have taken place in
the United States. As of 2014, the United States has won 2,400 medals at the
[Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games"),
more than any other country, and 281 in the [Winter Olympic
Games](/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games "Winter Olympic Games"), the second most
behind Norway.[638] While most major U.S. sports have evolved out of European
practices, [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"),
[volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball"),
[skateboarding](/wiki/Skateboarding "Skateboarding"), and
[snowboarding](/wiki/Snowboarding "Snowboarding") are American inventions,
some of which have become popular in other countries.
[Lacrosse](/wiki/Lacrosse "Lacrosse") and [surfing](/wiki/Surfing "Surfing")
arose from Native American and Native Hawaiian activities that predate Western
contact.[639] The most watched [individual sports](/wiki/Individual_sport
"Individual sport") are [golf](/wiki/Golf "Golf") and [auto
racing](/wiki/Auto_racing "Auto racing"), particularly [NASCAR](/wiki/NASCAR
"NASCAR").[640][641] [Rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") is
considered the fastest growing sport in the U.S., with registered players
numbered at 115,000+ and a further 1.2 million participants.[642]

### Media

Main article: [Media of the United States](/wiki/Media_of_the_United_States
"Media of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG/220px-
ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG)](/wiki/File:ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG "Enlarge")

The corporate headquarters of the [American Broadcasting
Company](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
in New York City

The four major broadcasters in the U.S. are the [National Broadcasting
Company](/wiki/NBC "NBC") (NBC), [Columbia Broadcasting System](/wiki/CBS
"CBS") (CBS), the [American Broadcasting
Company](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
(ABC), and [Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company").
The four major broadcast [television networks](/wiki/Television_network
"Television network") are all commercial entities. [Cable
television](/wiki/Cable_television_in_the_United_States "Cable television in
the United States") offers hundreds of channels catering to a variety of
niches.[643] Americans listen to radio programming, also largely commercial,
on average just over two-and-a-half hours a day.[644]

In 1998, the number of U.S. commercial radio stations had grown to 4,793 AM
stations and 5,662 FM stations. In addition, there are 1,460 public radio
stations. Most of these stations are run by universities and public
authorities for educational purposes and are financed by public or private
funds, subscriptions and corporate underwriting. Much public-radio
broadcasting is supplied by [NPR](/wiki/NPR "NPR") (formerly National Public
Radio). NPR was incorporated in February 1970 under the Public Broadcasting
Act of 1967; its television counterpart, [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS"), was also
created by the same legislation. (NPR and PBS are operated separately from
each other.) As of September 30,
2014[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit),
there are 15,433 licensed full-power radio stations in the U.S. according to
the [U.S. Federal Communications
Commission](/wiki/U.S._Federal_Communications_Commission "U.S. Federal
Communications Commission") (FCC).[645]

Well-known newspapers include _The[Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_, _The[New
York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ and _[USA
Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")_.[646] Although the cost of publishing has
increased over the years, the price of newspapers has generally remained low,
forcing newspapers to rely more on advertising revenue and on articles
provided by a major wire service, such as the Associated Press or Reuters, for
their national and world coverage. With very few exceptions, all the
newspapers in the U.S. are privately owned, either by large chains such as
[Gannett](/wiki/Gannett_Company "Gannett Company") or
[McClatchy](/wiki/The_McClatchy_Company "The McClatchy Company"), which own
dozens or even hundreds of newspapers; by small chains that own a handful of
papers; or in a situation that is increasingly rare, by individuals or
families. Major cities often have "alternative weeklies" to complement the
mainstream daily papers, for example, New York City's _[The Village
Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ or Los Angeles' _[LA
Weekly](/wiki/LA_Weekly "LA Weekly")_ , to name two of the best-known. Major
cities may also support a local business journal, trade papers relating to
local industries, and papers for local ethnic and social groups. Early
versions of the American newspaper [comic strip](/wiki/Comic_strip "Comic
strip") and the [American comic book](/wiki/American_comic_book "American
comic book") began appearing in the 19th century. In 1938,
[Superman](/wiki/Superman "Superman"), the comic book
[superhero](/wiki/Superhero "Superhero") of [DC Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC
Comics"), developed into an American icon.[647] Aside from [web
portals](/wiki/Web_portal "Web portal") and [search
engines](/wiki/Web_search_engine "Web search engine"), the most popular
websites are [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube
"YouTube"), [Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia "Wikipedia"), [Yahoo!](/wiki/Yahoo!
"Yahoo!"), [eBay](/wiki/EBay "EBay"), [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon.com "Amazon.com"),
and [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter").[648]

More than 800 publications are produced in Spanish, the second most commonly
used language in the United States behind English.[649][650]

## Science and technology

Main articles: [Science and technology in the United
States](/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States "Science and
technology in the United States") and [Science policy of the United
States](/wiki/Science_policy_of_the_United_States "Science policy of the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg/220px-
Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apollo_15_flag,_rover,_LM,_Irwin_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Apollo_15_flag,_rover,_LM,_Irwin_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

Astronaut [James Irwin](/wiki/James_Irwin "James Irwin") walking on the
[Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon") next to [Apollo 15](/wiki/Apollo_15 "Apollo 15")'s
[landing module](/wiki/Apollo_Lunar_Module "Apollo Lunar Module") and [lunar
rover](/wiki/Lunar_rover "Lunar rover") in 1971. The effort to reach the Moon
was triggered by the [Space Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race").

The United States has been a leader in technological innovation since the late
19th century and scientific research since the mid-20th century. Methods for
producing [interchangeable parts](/wiki/Interchangeable_parts "Interchangeable
parts") were developed by the U.S. War Department by the Federal Armories
during the first half of the 19th century. This technology, along with the
establishment of a [machine tool](/wiki/Machine_tool "Machine tool") industry,
enabled the U.S. to have large scale manufacturing of sewing machines,
bicycles and other items in the late 19th century and became known as the
[American system of manufacturing](/wiki/American_system_of_manufacturing
"American system of manufacturing"). Factory
[electrification](/wiki/Electrification "Electrification") in the early 20th
century and introduction of the [assembly line](/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly
line") and other labor saving techniques created the system called [mass
production](/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production").[651]

In 1876, [Alexander Graham Bell](/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell "Alexander Graham
Bell") was awarded the first U.S. [patent for the
telephone](/wiki/Invention_of_the_telephone "Invention of the telephone").
[Thomas Edison](/wiki/Thomas_Edison "Thomas Edison")'s [research
laboratory](/wiki/Research_institute "Research institute"), one of the first
of its kind, developed the [phonograph](/wiki/Phonograph "Phonograph"), the
first [long-lasting light bulb](/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb "Incandescent
light bulb"), and the first viable [movie camera](/wiki/Kinetoscope
"Kinetoscope").[652] The latter lead to emergence of the worldwide
[entertainment industry](/wiki/Show_business "Show business"). In the early
20th century, the automobile companies of [Ransom E.
Olds](/wiki/Ransom_E._Olds "Ransom E. Olds") and [Henry Ford](/wiki/Henry_Ford
"Henry Ford") popularized the [assembly line](/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly
line"). The [Wright brothers](/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers"), in
1903, made the [first sustained and controlled heavier-than-air powered
flight](/wiki/Wright_Flyer "Wright Flyer").[653]

The rise of [Fascism](/wiki/Fascism "Fascism") and [Nazism](/wiki/Nazism
"Nazism") in the 1920s and 1930s led many European scientists, including
[Albert Einstein](/wiki/Albert_Einstein "Albert Einstein"), [Enrico
Fermi](/wiki/Enrico_Fermi "Enrico Fermi"), and [John von
Neumann](/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von Neumann"), to immigrate to the
United States.[654] During World War II, the [Manhattan
Project](/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project") developed nuclear
weapons, ushering in the [Atomic Age](/wiki/Atomic_Age "Atomic Age"), while
the [Space Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race") produced rapid advances in
rocketry, [materials science](/wiki/Materials_science "Materials science"),
and [aeronautics](/wiki/Aeronautics "Aeronautics").[655][656]

The invention of the [transistor](/wiki/Transistor "Transistor") in the 1950s,
a key active component in practically all modern
[electronics](/wiki/Electronics "Electronics"), led to many technological
developments and a significant expansion of the U.S. technology
industry.[657][658][659] This in turn led to the establishment of many new
technology companies and regions around the country such as [Silicon
Valley](/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley") in California. Advancements by
American [microprocessor](/wiki/Microprocessor "Microprocessor") companies
such as [Advanced Micro Devices](/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices "Advanced Micro
Devices") (AMD), and [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel") along with both computer
[software](/wiki/Software "Software") and [hardware](/wiki/Computer_hardware
"Computer hardware") companies that include [Adobe
Systems](/wiki/Adobe_Systems "Adobe Systems"), [Apple Inc.](/wiki/Apple_Inc.
"Apple Inc."), [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM"), [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft
"Microsoft"), and [Sun Microsystems](/wiki/Sun_Microsystems "Sun
Microsystems") created and popularized the [personal
computer](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer"). The
[ARPANET](/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET") was developed in the 1960s to meet [Defense
Department](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States
Department of Defense") requirements, and became the first of a [series of
networks which evolved](/wiki/History_of_the_Internet "History of the
Internet") into the [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet").[660]

These advancements then lead to greater
[personalization](/wiki/Personalization "Personalization") of technology for
individual use.[661] As of
2013[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit),
83.8% of American households owned at least one [computer](/wiki/Computer
"Computer"), and 73.3% had high-speed Internet service.[662] 91% of Americans
also own a mobile phone as of May
2013[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit).[663]
The United States ranks highly with regard to freedom of use of the
internet.[664]

In the 21st century, approximately two-thirds of research and development
funding comes from the private sector.[665] The United States leads the world
in scientific research papers and [impact factor](/wiki/Impact_factor "Impact
factor").[666]

## Health

See also: [Health care in the United
States](/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States "Health care in the United
States"), [Health care reform in the United
States](/wiki/Health_care_reform_in_the_United_States "Health care reform in
the United States"), and [Health insurance in the United
States](/wiki/Health_insurance_in_the_United_States "Health insurance in the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-
Cornell.jpg/220px-NewYorkPresbyterian-
Cornell.jpg)](/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg "Enlarge")

[New York-Presbyterian Hospital](/wiki/New_York-Presbyterian_Hospital "New
York-Presbyterian Hospital") in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York
City") is one of the world's busiest [hospitals](/wiki/Hospital "Hospital").
Pictured is the [Weill
Cornell](/wiki/Weill_Cornell_Graduate_School_of_Medical_Sciences "Weill
Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences") facility (white complex at
center).

The United States has a life expectancy of 79.8 years at birth, up from 75.2
years in 1990.[667][668][669] The infant mortality rate of 6.17 per thousand
places the United States 56th-lowest out of 224 countries.[670]

Increasing [obesity in the United States](/wiki/Obesity_in_the_United_States
"Obesity in the United States") and health improvements elsewhere contributed
to lowering the country's rank in life expectancy from 11th in the world in
1987, to 42nd in 2007.[671] Obesity rates have more than doubled in the last
30 years, are the highest in the industrialized world, and are among the
highest anywhere.[672][673] Approximately one-third of the adult population is
obese and an additional third is overweight.[674] Obesity-related [type 2
diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus_type_2 "Diabetes mellitus type 2") is
considered epidemic by health care professionals.[675]

In 2010, [coronary artery disease](/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease "Coronary
artery disease"), [lung cancer](/wiki/Lung_cancer "Lung cancer"),
[stroke](/wiki/Stroke "Stroke"), [chronic obstructive pulmonary
diseases](/wiki/Chronic_obstructive_pulmonary_disease "Chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease"), and traffic accidents caused the most years of life lost
in the U.S. Low back pain, [depression](/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder "Major
depressive disorder"), [musculoskeletal
disorders](/wiki/Musculoskeletal_disorder "Musculoskeletal disorder"), neck
pain, and [anxiety](/wiki/Anxiety "Anxiety") caused the most years lost to
disability. The most deleterious [risk factors](/wiki/Risk_factor "Risk
factor") were poor diet, tobacco smoking, obesity, [high blood
pressure](/wiki/Hypertension "Hypertension"), [high blood
sugar](/wiki/Hyperglycemia "Hyperglycemia"), [physical
inactivity](/wiki/Physical_inactivity "Physical inactivity"), and alcohol use.
[Alzheimer's disease](/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease "Alzheimer's disease"), drug
abuse, [kidney disease](/wiki/Kidney_disease "Kidney disease"), cancer, and
falls caused the most additional years of life lost over their age-adjusted
1990 per-capita rates.[669] U.S. teenage pregnancy and abortion rates are
substantially higher than in other Western nations, especially among blacks
and Hispanics.[676]

The U.S. is a global leader in medical innovation. America solely developed or
contributed significantly to 9 of the top 10 most important medical
innovations since 1975 as ranked by a 2001 poll of physicians, while the
European Union and Switzerland together contributed to five.[677] Since 1966,
more Americans have received the [Nobel Prize in
Medicine](/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Physiology_or_Medicine "List of
Nobel laureates in Physiology or Medicine") than the rest of the world
combined. From 1989 to 2002, four times more money was invested in private
biotechnology companies in America than in Europe.[678] The U.S. health-care
system far
[outspends](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_health_expenditure_\(PPP\)_per_capita
"List of countries by total health expenditure \(PPP\) per capita") any other
nation, measured in both per capita spending and percentage of GDP.[679]

Health-care coverage in the United States is a combination of public and
private efforts and is not [universal](/wiki/Universal_health_care "Universal
health care"). In 2014, 13.4% of the population did not carry [health
insurance](/wiki/Health_insurance "Health insurance").[680] The subject of
uninsured and underinsured Americans is a major political issue.[681][682] In
2006, [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts") became the first
state to mandate universal health insurance.[683] [Federal
legislation](/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient
Protection and Affordable Care Act") passed in early 2010 would ostensibly
create a near-universal health insurance system around the country by 2014,
though the bill and its ultimate effect are issues of controversy.[684][685]

[Algonquian](/wiki/Algonquian_languages "Algonquian languages"), [Cherokee](/wiki/Cherokee_language "Cherokee language"), and [Sioux](/wiki/Sioux_language "Sioux language") are among many other official languages in Native-controlled lands throughout the country. [French](/wiki/French_language "French language") is a _de facto_ , but unofficial, language in [Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine") and [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), while [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico") law grants [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language") a special status.[4][5]
  3. **Jump up ^** In five territories, English as well as one or more indigenous languages are official: [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language") in Puerto Rico, [Samoan](/wiki/Samoan_language "Samoan language") in American Samoa, [Chamorro](/wiki/Chamorro_language "Chamorro language") in both Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. [Carolinian](/wiki/Carolinian_language "Carolinian language") is also an official language in the Northern Mariana Islands.
