There are eleven smaller island areas without permanent populations: [Baker Island](/wiki/Baker_Island "Baker Island"), [Howland Island](/wiki/Howland_Island "Howland Island"), [Jarvis Island](/wiki/Jarvis_Island "Jarvis Island"), [Johnston Atoll](/wiki/Johnston_Atoll "Johnston Atoll"), [Kingman Reef](/wiki/Kingman_Reef "Kingman Reef"), [Midway Atoll](/wiki/Midway_Atoll "Midway Atoll"), and [Palmyra Atoll](/wiki/Palmyra_Atoll "Palmyra Atoll"). U.S. sovereignty over [Bajo Nuevo Bank](/wiki/Bajo_Nuevo_Bank "Bajo Nuevo Bank"), [Navassa Island](/wiki/Navassa_Island "Navassa Island"), [Serranilla Bank](/wiki/Serranilla_Bank "Serranilla Bank"), and [Wake Island](/wiki/Wake_Island "Wake Island") is disputed.[16]
  7. **Jump up ^** The _Encyclopædia Britannica_ lists China as world's third-largest country (after Russia and Canada) with a total area of 9,572,900 sq km,[18] and the United States as fourth-largest at 9,526,468 sq km. The figure for the United States is less than in the _CIA World Factbook_ because it _excludes_ coastal and territorial waters.[19]

The _CIA World Factbook_ lists the United States as the third-largest country
(after Russia and Canada) with total area of 9,833,517 sq km,[20] and China as
fourth-largest at 9,596,960 sq km.[21] This figure for the United States is
greater than in the _Encyclopædia Britannica_ because it _includes_ coastal
and territorial waters.

  8. **Jump up ^** Spain sent [several expeditions to Alaska](/wiki/Spanish_expeditions_to_the_Pacific_Northwest "Spanish expeditions to the Pacific Northwest") to assert its long-held claim over the Pacific Northwest which dated back to the 16th century. During the decade 1785–1795 British merchants, encouraged by [Sir Joseph Banks](/wiki/Sir_Joseph_Banks "Sir Joseph Banks") and supported by their government, made a sustained attempt to develop this trade despite Spain's claims and navigation rights. The endeavours of these merchants did not last long in the face of Spain's opposition. The challenge was also opposed by a Japan holding obdurately to national seclusion.[88]
  9. **Jump up ^** His previous arrival coincided with the [Makahiki](/wiki/Makahiki "Makahiki"),[102] a festival celebrating the [Hawaiian deity](/wiki/Hawaiian_religion "Hawaiian religion") [Lono](/wiki/Lono "Lono").[103] After the [HMS  _Resolution_](/wiki/HMS_Resolution_\(1771\) "HMS Resolution \(1771\)") and [HMS  _Discovery_](/wiki/HMS_Discovery_\(1774\) "HMS Discovery \(1774\)") had left the islands, the season for battle and war had begun under the worship and rituals for [Kūkaʻilimoku](/wiki/K%C5%AB "Kū"), the [Hawaiian deity](/wiki/Hawaiian_religion "Hawaiian religion") of war.[104]
  10. **Jump up ^** On the evening of February 13, while anchored in Kealakekua Bay after their return, one of only two long boats was stolen.[105] The Hawaiians had begun to openly challenging the foreigners. In retaliation, Cook tried to take the [aliʻi nui](/wiki/Ali%CA%BBi "Aliʻi") of the island of Hawaii, [Kalaniʻōpuʻu](/wiki/Kalani%CA%BB%C5%8Dpu%CA%BBu "Kalaniʻōpuʻu") as ransom for the boats.[106] The following morning of February 14, 1779[107] Cook and his men went directly to Kalaniʻōpuʻu's enclosure where the monarch was still sleeping.[108] One of ruler's wives, [Kānekapōlei](/wiki/K%C4%81nekap%C5%8Dlei "Kānekapōlei") pleaded with them to stop.[109] Cook's men and the Marines were confronted on the beach by thousands of [Native Hawaiians](/wiki/Native_Hawaiians "Native Hawaiians").[110] Cook tried to move the elderly man but he refused. As the townspeople began to surrounding them, Cook and his men raised their guns. Two chiefs and the monarch's wife shielded Kalaniʻōpuʻu as Cook tried to force him to his feet.[111] The crowd became hostile and [Kanaʻina](/wiki/Kana%CA%BBina "Kanaʻina") (one of the monarch's attendants) approached Cook, who reacted by striking him with the broad side of his sword. Kanaʻina instantly grabbed Cook and lifted him off his feet.[112] Kanaʻina released Cook, who fell to the ground as another attendant, Nuaa fatally stabbed Cook to death.[113]
  11. **Jump up ^** The United States has a very diverse population; 37 [ancestry groups](/wiki/U.s._ancestry "U.s. ancestry") have more than one million members.[262] [German Americans](/wiki/German_American "German American") are the largest ethnic group (more than 50 million) – followed by [Irish Americans](/wiki/Irish_American "Irish American") (circa 37 million), [Mexican Americans](/wiki/Mexican_American "Mexican American") (circa 31 million) and [English Americans](/wiki/English_American "English American") (circa 28 million).[263][264] [White Americans](/wiki/White_American "White American") are the largest [racial group](/wiki/Race_\(human_classification\) "Race \(human classification\)"); [black Americans](/wiki/African_American "African American") are the nation's largest [racial minority](/wiki/Minority_group "Minority group") (note that in the U.S. Census, [Hispanic and Latino Americans](/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans "Hispanic and Latino Americans") are counted as an _ethnic_ group, not a "racial" group), and third-largest ancestry group.[262] [Asian Americans](/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American") are the country's second-largest racial minority; the three largest Asian American ethnic groups are [Chinese Americans](/wiki/Chinese_American "Chinese American"), [Filipino Americans](/wiki/Filipino_American "Filipino American"), and [Indian Americans](/wiki/Indian_American "Indian American").[262]
  12. **Jump up ^** [Fertility](/wiki/Fertility "Fertility") is also a factor; in 2010 the average Hispanic woman gave birth to 2.35 children in her lifetime, compared to 1.97 for non-Hispanic black women and 1.79 for non-Hispanic white women (both below the [replacement rate](/wiki/Replacement_rates "Replacement rates") of 2.1).[281] [Minorities](/wiki/Minority_group "Minority group") (as defined by the Census Bureau as all those beside non-Hispanic, non-multiracial whites) constituted 36.3% of the population in 2010 (this is nearly 40% in 2015),[282] and over 50% of children under age one,[283] and are projected to constitute the majority by 2042.[284] This contradicts the report by the National Vital Statistics Reports, based on the U.S. census data, which concludes that 54% (2,162,406 out of 3,999,386 in 2010) of births were non-Hispanic white.[281] The Hispanic birth rate plummeted 25% between 2006 and 2013 while the rate for non-Hispanics decreased just 5%.[285]
  13. **Jump up ^** Source: 2015 [American Community Survey](/wiki/American_Community_Survey "American Community Survey"), [U.S. Census Bureau](/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau "U.S. Census Bureau"). Most respondents who speak a language other than English at home also report speaking English "well" or "very well" For the language groups listed above, the strongest English-language proficiency is among speakers of German (96% report that they speak English "well" or "very well"), followed by speakers of French (93.5%), Tagalog (92.8%), Spanish (74.1%), Korean (71.5%), Chinese (70.4%), and Vietnamese (66.9%).
  14. **Jump up ^** In January 2015, U.S. federal government debt held by the public was approximately $13 trillion, or about 72% of U.S. GDP. Intra-governmental holdings stood at $5 trillion, giving a combined total debt of $18.080 trillion.[413][414] By 2012, total federal debt had surpassed 100% of U.S. GDP.[415] The U.S. has a [credit rating](/wiki/Credit_rating "Credit rating") of AA+ from [Standard & Poor's](/wiki/Standard_%26_Poor%27s "Standard & Poor's"), AAA from [Fitch](/wiki/Fitch_Ratings "Fitch Ratings"), and AAA from [Moody's](/wiki/Moody%27s_Investors_Service "Moody's Investors Service").[416]
  15. **Jump up ^** The [Stockholm International Peace Research Institute](/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute "Stockholm International Peace Research Institute"), SIPRI, found that the United States' [arms industry](/wiki/Arms_industry "Arms industry") was the world's biggest exporter of major weapons from 2005 to 2009,[480] and remained the largest exporter of major weapons during a period between 2010 and 2014, followed by Russia, China (PRC), and Germany.[481]
  16. **Jump up ^** Droughts are likely to particularly affect the 66 percent of Americans whose communities depend on surface water.[557] As for drinking water quality, there are concerns about disinfection by-products, [lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead"), [perchlorates](/wiki/Perchlorates "Perchlorates") and pharmaceutical substances, but generally [drinking water quality in the U.S.](/wiki/Drinking_water_quality_in_the_United_States "Drinking water quality in the United States") is good.[558]
